But with the entire match card now announced, it's time to take a look at what is going to go down on Sunday.\n\nIt is all set to go down live from Brooklyn beginning at 7 p.m. ET on Sunday, August 20. The kickoff show will start two hours earlier at 5 p.m. ET and all action can be watched live nationally on WWE Network.\n\nBig fan of WWE? Be sure to subscribe to our podcast In This Corner with Brian Campbell where we break down everything you need to know each week.\n\n2017 WWE SummerSlam matches\n\nUniversal Championship -- Brock Lesnar (c) vs. Roman Reigns vs. Samoa Joe vs. Braun Strowman (Fatal 4-Way): There will be more than 1,200 pounds of mass in this match, which should be the main event of the card. Paul Heyman added a stipulation that Lesnar will leave WWE if he loses the title due to a Fatal 4-Way being unfair to the champion.\n\nWWE Championship -- Jinder Mahal (c) vs. Shinsuke Nakamura: It was long expected that Cena would be the one to fight and defeat Mahal, but Nakamura beat Cena clean to become the No. 1 contender for the WWE title. There has been no build otherwise for this match.\n\nUnited States Championship -- AJ Styles (c) vs. Kevin Owens: The fourth time they will meet with the title on the line in a televised match, Styles and Owens will do so this time with SmackDown commissioner Shane McMahon serving as the special guest referee. This one should finally result in a ... somewhat-decisive finish.\n\nFinn Balor vs. Bray Wyatt: This feud finally came to a head Monday on Raw when Wyatt beat Balor clean and appeared to dump blood on him after the match. Backstage, Balor teased the return of the Demon King at SummerSlam.\n\nRaw Women's Championship -- Alexa Bliss (c) vs. Sasha Banks: Though Baley earned the No. 1 contendership, a shoulder injury has forced her from SummerSlam. Banks beat Nia Jax in a No. 1 contendership match on Monday.\n\nSmackDown Women's Championship -- Naomi (c) vs. Natalya: Earning her shot by winning a Fatal 5-Way match at Battleground, Natalya will look to win her first \"women's\" championship after previously being divas champion for two months. This match will likely take place on the kickoff show.\n\nRaw Tag Team Championship -- Sheamus & Cesaro (c) vs. Dean Ambrose & Seth Rollins: Moments after Ambrose and Rollins reunited, general manager Kurt Angle locked in a tag team championship match for SummerSlam.\n\nJohn Cena vs. Baron Corbin: Corbin attacked Nakamura and Cena came to the aid of the King of Strong Style on SmackDown by putting Corbin through the announce table. Daniel Bryan made the match official on Tuesday.\n\nRandy Orton vs. Rusev: Not exactly sure who came up with this one.\n\nBig Show vs. Big Cass: Enzo Amore will be suspended above the ring in a shark cage. This should be on the kickoff show, one would hope.\n\nSmackDown Tag Team Championship -- The New Day (c) vs. The Usos (Kickoff Show): New Day won the titles at Battleground, so a rematch makes plenty of sense. There are no other tag teams on the show really deserving of the spotlight anyway.\n\nCruiserweight Championship -- Akira Tozawa (c) vs. Neville (Kickoff Show): After Tozawa surprisingly beat Neville clean for the title on Raw, the former champion gets his rematch at SummerSlam.\n\nJason Jordan & The Hardy Boyz vs. The Miz & The Miztourage (Kickoff Show): Good way to get six guys on the show who definitely needed to be featured. Since the inaugural SummerSlam in 1988, the event has been held in 13 different states, as well as in Canada and England. Mahal will become the third superstar in WWE history to defend the WWE Championship in his SummerSlam debut. Each of the previous two lost the match yet retained the title.\n\nUnited States Championship: AJ Styles (c) v. Kevin Owens\n\n- Shane McMahon will be the special guest referee for this match, and that could be bad news for Styles. He has lost at each of the past six SummerSlam events, including five WWE Championship matches. Cena's last SummerSlam victory came in 2010 when Cena and \"Team WWE\" defeated \"Team Nexus\" in a 7-on-7 elimination tag team match. Overall, Cena has lost nine times at SummerSlam, his most losses at any pay-per-view event.\n\n- Corbin is the only WWE superstar to win both a Money in the Bank ladder match and an Andre the Giant Memorial Battle Royal.\n\n- After going 6-1 at pay-per-view events in his debut year in 2016, Corbin is just 1-5 in 2017. Roman Reigns, Braun Strowman and Samoa Joe - in the main event.\n\nWWE Champion Jinder Mahal defends SmackDown's most prestigious title against the 'Rockstar' Shinsuke Nakamura.\n\nAJ Styles and Kevin Owens will compete for the US Championship, while Baron Corbin is out for revenge against John Cena.\n\nRaw's women's title is up for grabs as Sasha Banks challenges Alexa Bliss and SmackDown's equivalent sees Naomi battle Natalya.\n\nMeanwhile Raw Tag Team Champions Sheamus and Cesaro look to resist the newly-reunited Seth Rollins and Dean Ambrose.\n\nHere is a match-by-match breakdown of the show.\n\nSingles match for the WWE Cruiserweight Championship\n\nAkira Tozawa (c) (with Titus O'Neil) vs. Neville\n\nJust six days before their scheduled SummerSlam clash, Akira Tozawa dethroned Neville to become the WWE Cruiserweight Championship on Monday Night Raw. An uncharacteristic mistake from Newcastle's high flyer allowed the Japanese challenger to hit his massive diving senton for the win and celebrate with his Titus Brand team mates Titus O'Neil and Apollo Crews. The rematch for the title with the former King of the Cruiserweights gunning for revenge will now take place on the Kickoff pre-show. While it initially seemed a little odd to have Tozawa capture the belt ahead of the second biggest show of the year, it made sense in hindsight, as he and Neville were given time to tell a story and give the title switch the attention it deserved. This encounter will likely be an entertaining but much quicker affair, which presumably will end with Neville falling short in his bid to regain the gold.\n\nPredicted winner: Akira Tozawa\n\nTag team match for the WWE SmackDown Tag Team Championship\n\nThe New Day (Big E and Xavier Woods) (c) (with Kofi Kingston) vs. The Usos (Jimmy Uso and Jey Uso)\n\nThe New Day defeated The Usos at Battleground to win the SmackDown Tag Team Championship following a tremendous match, which undoubtedly stole the show. It was great to see the lesser light of the New Day, Xavier Woods, play such a pivotal role in guiding his friends Kofi Kingston and Big E to glory. The rivalry between two of the best tag teams in WWE of the last decade has lived up to all expectations and it's therefore something of a strange decision to see this rematch relegated to the Kickoff pre-show. Since the New Day clinched the titles the furious Usos have ambushed and assaulted them, demanding retribution. Hopefully they will still get enough time to add another great bout to the feud, but it would be surprising to see the belts change hands.\n\nPredicted winner: The New Day\n\nSix-man tag team match\n\nThe Hardy Boyz (Jeff and Matt Hardy) and Jason Jordan vs. The Miz and The Miztourage (Bo Dallas and Curtis Axel) (with Maryse)\n\nThere has been no stranger WWE storyline in recent memory than the decision to have Raw General Manager Kurt Angle reveal that Jason Jordan is his illegitimate son after weeks of Raw commentator Corey Graves receiving secretive text messages about the former Olympic Gold Medallist's personal life. Fans have struggled to get on board with this classic piece of Vince McMahon inspired madness and predictably begun to boo Jordan, who is being presented as someone they should be cheering.\n\nJordan is of course a very talented wrestler, but quite whether this will benefit him in the long term remains to be seen. He has a chance here to record his first big win as he teams up with eternal fan favourites The Hardy Boyz against the devious Intercontinental Champion The Miz and his new lackeys, The Miztourage, aka Bo Dallas and Curtis Axel, in a six-man tag team match. Not even the calculating Maryse at ringside can surely win this one for her man.\n\nPredicted winners: The Hardy Boyz and Jason Jordan\n\nSingles match\n\nRandy Orton vs. Rusev\n\nRusev got more than he bargained for on the August 1 episode of SmackDown, when he issued a SummerSlam 'Open Challenge' which was answered by the 13-time world champion Randy Orton, who promptly hit him with an RKO. The Viper is coming off the back of an underwhelming run as WWE Champion, but is still one of the biggest stars in the company, who can always work a strong match. The outcome of this bout could say a lot about WWE's plans for both him and the Bulgarian Brute, who last month lost a hard fought flag match with his old foe John Cena, which truth be told, no one expected him to win. Presumably Orton won't be returning to the main event scene on Tuesday nights anytime soon, so why not push a younger, talented star who has the potential to be one of the top heels on the roster?\n\nPredicted winner: Rusev\n\nSingles match for the WWE SmackDown Women's Championship\n\nNaomi (c) vs. Natalya\n\nNatalya made her thoughts on Naomi adding LED lights to the SmackDown Women's Championship very clear when she criticised her for turning the title into a \"toy\". The Queen of Harts continued by claiming Naomi did not respect the Hart family and that she would bring honour to the title by claiming it from the fun-loving champ. She and Naomi have a lot of experience and could wage a cracking battle here. But the spectre in the background is of course Miss Money In The Bank herself, Carmella, who defeated Naomi on SmackDown recently with the help of the returning James Ellsworth, who so controversially helped her win the briefcase. With Baron Corbin having blown his Money In The Bank cash-in last Tuesday, could we see a successful rendition tomorrow night from the Princess of Staten Island? Don't be surprised if Naomi retains but a cunning Carmella takes advantage of a weakened opponent to walk out of SummerSlam with the belt.\n\nPredicted winner: Naomi\n\nSingles match\n\nBig Show (with Enzo Amore) vs. Big Cass\n\nBig Cass betraying Enzo Amore not once, but twice, before squashing him at Great Balls of Fire, was a sight to behold. Amore is a master of the microphone but still needs a lot of work to be portrayed as a viable in-ring threat. Cass meanwhile is 7ft tall and everyone knows, you can't teach that. He is improving step by step when it comes to promos and already looks the real deal due to his combination of size and power. Standing across the ring from him at the Barclays Center will be another giant, Big Show, but a snide attack by Cass assisted by Luke Gallows and Karl Anderson in which they targeted his right hand has supposedly removed the most devastating move in Show's arsenal. his KO Punch. The wildcard in this match is Amore, who will be suspended above the ring in a shark cage. If he does get involved, perhaps Gallows and Anderson will again play a part. But looking towards the future, Cass has to be the one who comes out on top here.\n\nPredicted winner: Big Cass\n\nSingles match\n\nJohn Cena vs. Baron Corbin\n\nMr Money In The Bank Baron Corbin riled John Cena when he launched a sneak attack on Shinsuke Nakamura after the 'Rockstar' defeated Cena to become number one contender to the WWE Championship. The 16-time world champion decided to come to Nakamura's aid and as a result hit Corbin with an AA through the announcers' table. A match was made between Corbin and Cena at SummerSlam, before Baron decided to intervene in a contest between the face of the company and the WWE Champion Jinder Mahal. He attacked Cena, then cashed-in his contract on a vulnerable Mahal, who has just received a super AA from Cena. But a distraction from John allowed Jinder to quickly roll-up Corbin and escape with his belt. On the one hand, it seems to have derailed all momentum that Corbin was building and made him look something of a fool. But if he brings a ferocious response to this clash and downs Cena at the second biggest pay-per-view of the year, that would be a huge step back in the right direction for the Lone Wolf.\n\nPredicted winner: Baron Corbin\n\nTag team match for the WWE Raw Tag Team Championship\n\nSheamus and Cesaro (c) vs. Seth Rollins and Dean Ambrose\n\nOver the past year Sheamus and Cesaro have proved themselves to be the best tag team in all of WWE - an unlikely duo who were once bitter rivals but have become a well-oiled machine. The Europeans overcame the challenge of the Attitude Era legends The Hardy Boyz in an epic Iron Man match at Great Balls of Fire, but now face a pair of modern tag greats, the reunited Dean Ambrose and Seth Rollins, aka two thirds of the dominant faction The Shield. Rollins of course betrayed Ambrose and the third man in that group, Roman Reigns, in the most despicable of fashion three years ago when he beat them down with a steel chair and joined forces with Triple H and The Authority.\n\nHaving enjoyed a long run as heel WWE Champion, then suffered and overcome serious knee injuries, he turned face and defeated his former mentor The Game at WrestleMania. But Ambrose wasn't going to forgive him quickly and WWE have teased a slow burning reunion, which was finally realised last week on Raw when they performed their signature fist bump. There is no doubt this will be a cracking match - these two teams are just too talented for that not to be the case. But how will it be resolved? Perhaps the most satisfying scenario would be Sheamus and Cesaro prevailing and Ambrose turning heel on Rollins - reigniting the career of the Lunatic Fringe.\n\nPredicted winners: Sheamus and Cesaro\n\nSingles match\n\nFinn Balor vs. Bray Wyatt\n\nFinn Balor has never quite recovered the momentum he had when he became the inaugural WWE Universal Champion at SummerSlam last year by defeating Seth Rollins, thanks to the injury he suffered on the night he was crowned king of the mountain. After a long injury lay-off he returned to Raw and set about challenging Brock Lesnar and inserting himself in the main event picture. But he's been toiling away in a feud with the guitar-playing Elias and now finds himself embroiled in a contest with Bray Wyatt, who has been lumbering along since his abortive WWE Championship run ended at the hands of Randy Orton at WrestleMania and then in ignominy in the House of Horrors.\n\nBray did record a rare pay-per-view win, besting Seth Rollins at Great Balls of Fire, and seemingly coating Balor in blood on Raw was a new trick, but it's hard to see any outcome here other than Balor recording the win he needs to boost his standing ahead of another tilt at Raw's top prize. Especially when Wyatt has dared him to unleash his Demon King persona, which should at least ensure he has the most theatrical and impressive entrance of the evening.\n\nPredicted winner: Finn Balor\n\nSingles match for the WWE United States Championship\n\nAJ Styles (c) vs. Kevin Owens\n\nThe United States Championship showdown is an obvious contender for the match of the night, even if AJ Styles and Kevin Owens's feud hasn't quite matched fans' lofty expectations so far. After losing the strap at a house shown in Madison Square Garden, Owens recaptured the belt from Styles in a bout that looked like it was building into a classic, but fell short, at Battleground. AJ then won it back again in a triple threat encounter also including Chris Jericho on SmackDown, when he actually pinned Y2J, not KO, to clinch the belt.\n\nWhen Owens lost his rematch despite the fact both of his shoulders were not on the mat, he blasted a referee and demanded another shot. SmackDown General Manager Daniel Bryan agreed and made SmackDown commissioner Shane McMahon the special guest referee. Shane O'Mac has promised to call the match fairly. However, a subsequent brawl saw AJ accidentally kick Shane, and it's only a matter of months since he hurled him through a car window and beat the hell out of him at WrestleMania. Could we see Shane turn on AJ? It's a real possibility.\n\nPredicted winner: Kevin Owens\n\nSingles match for the WWE Raw Women's Championship\n\nAlexa Bliss (c) vs. Sasha Banks\n\nAlexa Bliss has managed to cling onto her Raw Women's Championship in all manner of ways - by destroying Bayley, dodging the challenge of Nia Jax and getting herself counted-out against Sasha Banks. With Bayley succumbing to a legitimate injury, she will not get a shot at redemption tomorrow night. Instead the duty falls to Banks, who very impressively forced Jax to submit to a Bank Statement on Raw this week. Banks is without doubt the top female competitor on Monday nights and she and Bliss could produce another very entertaining clash, as they did at Great Balls of Fire. However, if the plan originally was for Bayley rather than her to even be involved in this contest, then perhaps we shouldn't expect The Boss to regain the title she held on so many occasions last year.\n\nPredicted winner: Alexa Bliss\n\nSingles match for the WWE Championship\n\nJinder Mahal (c) (with The Singh Brothers) vs. Shinsuke Nakamura\n\nThe unlikeliest WWE Champion in history continues to prove the critics wrong heading into SummerSlam as Jinder Mahal prepares to face Shinsuke Nakamura. Having defeated Randy Orton some three times with the help of The Singh Brothers (including in a Punjabi Prison match where he also called on his mentor The Great Khali for assistance, in the most bizarre WWE return of 2017) who would bet against the Modern Day Maharajah withstanding the challenge of Nakamura?\n\nShinsuke hasn't quite connected with fans on the main roster like he did in NXT, perhaps due to a series of misfiring promos, which have done nothing but expose the one weakness the ring technician possesses when trying to engage fans in a second language. Defeating John Cena to become number one contender is certainly the way to assert your credentials, but this doesn't feel like the right time for the coronation of Nakamura as WWE Champion and would undo a lot of the hard work put in by WWE to try and establish Mahal as a genuine main event star.\n\nPredicted winner: Jinder Mahal\n\nFatal 4-Way match for the WWE Universal Championship\n\nBrock Lesnar (c)(with Paul Heyman) vs. Roman Reigns vs. Samoa Joe vs. Braun Strowman\n\nSome main events just have an extra special feel about them and this is certainly one of those contests. The four most dominant forces on Raw will collide in a battle of the behemoths when Universal Champion Brock Lesnar is challenged by WWE golden boy Roman Reigns, the monstrous Braun Strowman and dangerous wildcard Samoa Joe. Lesnar, who has again been teasing a return to UFC, has threatened to leave WWE if he loses this match because he is supposedly unhappy at having to defend his title against three opponents. Can the master of the F5 retain his prized title, or will he walk away from the company yet again?\n\nThere are so many interesting angles to this boutt, none more so than the brutal rivalry of Reigns and Strowman, which culminated in Roman attempting to end Braun once and for all at Great Balls of Fire by reversing an ambulance with him inside into a truck! Their feud has in many ways dominated WWE television in 2017. Then there is Joe, who was introduced as the hired gun of the now absent Triple H, who came close to beating Lesnar last month and has been presented as a genuine threat to the Beast Incarnate in a way few men - Goldberg aside - have been over the past few years. Having waited over a decade for a crack at the big time in WWE, Joe has seized the opportunity with both hands and it would be fantastic to see him emerge victorious here.\n\nLesnar is a huge fan favourite because he is a bona fide badass who lays waste to all before him, as we saw when he delivered a round of F5s to the Miz and the Miztourage a fortnight ago. But a situation where the Universal Champion is a part timer - however much excitement that generates when he does compete - cannot be ideal going forwards. A break for Lesnar as a result of him losing his belt but never actually being pinned or submitted might be the ideal solution and how great would it be if Joe was the one to capitalise?\n\nPredicted winner: Samoa Joe\n\nWatch WWE SummerSlam 2017 live on the WWE Network or on Sky Sports Box Office at midnight on Sunday, August 20.\n\nYou can follow all the action as it happens in the Mirror Sport SummerSlam 2017 Live Blog.\n\nWWE Live returns to the UK this November, tickets available at www.bookingsdirect.com.\n\nRead More WWE Mirror Exclusive interviews", "dateTime": "2017-08-19T22:58:00Z", "extractedDates": [{"textEnd": 4128, "textStart": 4120, "imp": true, "date": "2017-08-01", "amb": false}, {"textEnd": 16212, "textStart": 16203, "imp": true, "date": "2017-08-20", "amb": false}], "sim": 0.800000011920929, "dateCrawl": "2017-08-19", "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3373948", "time": "22:58:00", "lang": "eng", "eventUri": "eng-3364258", "location": null, "concepts": [{"id": "233", "label": {"eng": "United States"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States", "type": "loc", "location": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}, "score": 4}, {"id": "303298", "type": "wiki", "label": {"eng": "Professional wrestling attacks"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Professional_wrestling_attacks", "score": 2}, {"id": "304688", "type": "wiki", "label": {"eng": "Glossary of professional wrestling terms"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Glossary_of_professional_wrestling_terms", "score": 3}, {"id": "306411", "type": "wiki", "label": {"eng": "Professional wrestling"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Professional_wrestling", "score": 2}, {"id": "307120", "type": "wiki", "label": {"eng": "Face (professional wrestling)"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Face_(professional_wrestling)", "score": 5}, {"id": "315013", "type": "person", "label": {"eng": "A.J. {"id": "10048531", "categories": [{"id": 144, "label": "dmoz/Science/Technology/Energy", "uri": "dmoz/Science/Technology/Energy", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 261, "label": "dmoz/Computers/Internet/Web Design and Development", "uri": "dmoz/Computers/Internet/Web_Design_and_Development", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 347, "label": "dmoz/Shopping/Toys and Games/Trading Cards", "uri": "dmoz/Shopping/Toys_and_Games/Trading_Cards", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 393, "label": "dmoz/Sports/Motorsports/Auto Racing", "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Motorsports/Auto_Racing", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 557, "label": "dmoz/Society/Relationships/Dating", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Relationships/Dating", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 710, "label": "dmoz/Games/Gambling/Sports", "uri": "dmoz/Games/Gambling/Sports", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 728, "label": "dmoz/Computers/Software/Operating Systems", "uri": "dmoz/Computers/Software/Operating_Systems", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 1184, "label": "dmoz/Sports/Wrestling/Professional", "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Wrestling/Professional", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-19", "uri": "711873099", "source": {"id": "246", "title": "International Business Times", "uri": "ibtimes.com"}, "url": "http://www.ibtimes.com/wwe-summerslam-2017-betting-odds-start-time-live-stream-info-ppv-2580229", "body": "The build towards WWE SummerSlam 2017 hasn't been as entertaining as it's been in recent years, but you might not know that by looking at the card. The pay-per-view is almost being treated like WrestleMania, considering it features 12 advertised matches and could last longer than five hours.\n\nThe kickoff show starts at 6 p.m. EDT, and the actual pay-per-view gets underway an hour later at 7 p.m. EDT at Barclays Center in Brooklyn. Fans can either watch the SummerSlam with a live stream on the WWE Network, or they can order the PPV for $54.99. A subscription to the network costs $9.99 per month, though new subscribers get the first month free.\n\nIf the SummerSlam betting odds are any indication, the two world title matches shouldn't be very difficult to predict. Brock Lesnar is a significant favorite to successfully defend his WWE Universal Championship against Roman Reigns, Braun Strowman and Samoa Joe. Jinder Mahal has been the WWE Champion since he won the title at Backlash, but Shinsuke Nakamura has -500 odds to take the belt from him.\n\nThe most difficult match to call might be the Cruiserweight Championship Match. Akira Tozawa has even odds six days after beating Neville for the title. Neville had been the champion since Royal Rumble.\n\nJohn Cena is a -200 favorite against Baron Corbin, five days after he caused the Money in the Bank winner to fail during his cash-in attempt. Rusev is a -200 favorite against Randy Orton.\n\nFinn Balor is the biggest favorite at SummerSlam. He's expected to beat Bray Wyatt in their rematch from \"Monday Night Raw\" as he brings back his \"demon\" persona for the first time since SummerSlam 2016.\n\nBrock Lesnar, pictured at Barclays Center of Brooklyn on Aug. 23, 2015 in New York City, has the best betting odds to win the WWE Universal Championship Match at SummerSlam 2017. Nakamura interrupts Mahal's Independence Day celebrations\n\nThroughout Jinder Mahal's WWE Championship reign, we have seen exuberant celebrations and great patriotism from Mahal, attempting to bring Indian culture to so-called 'xenophobic' fans across the United States.\n\nTuesday was no different, as Mahal announced that it was Indian Independence Day, and it was time to celebrate that fact. Mahal and The Singh Brothers led the celebrations, which included dancers and even a woman signing the Indian national anthem, which was met with a chorus of boos in Providence, Rhode Island.\n\nMahal's opponent at Summerslam, Shinsuke Nakamura, eventually arrived to interrupt the party, batting down Mahal's accusations of disrespect by stating that Tuesday was also an important day in his native Japan, as it was a day to pray for peace and remember those fallen in war - but Nakamura's appearance wasn't without a warning shot, as he pointed out that Sunday is an important day in America, as it will be the day that he takes the WWE Championship from Mahal.\n\n2. Natalya warms up for Summerslam by beating Becky Lynch\n\nHaving won the Fatal Five-Way at Battleground, Natalya will face Naomi for the Smackdown Women's Championship at Summerslam - and she took on Becky Lynch ahead of that meeting this Sunday.\n\nNaomi watched on from the commentary table as Natalya claimed the win, forcing Lynch to tap out to her Sharpshooter submission hold, though she was chased away from the ring by Naomi after locking in the Sharpshooter again after the bell had rung.\n\nAs Natalya attempted to make her exit, Carmella - the Money in the Bank contract holder - emerged alongside the newly-reinstated James Ellsworth, reminding both Naomi and Natalya that, whoever wins on Sunday, they will have to prepare for Carmella's cash-in, which may well come at Summerslam.\n\n3. Lana and Tamina vow to become unstoppable\n\nIn recent weeks, we have seen Lana and Tamina forge a surprise alliance in the women's division, though their relationship has been strained in recent weeks.\n\nThis week, Tamina complained that she hasn't had a title opportunity yet whereas Lana - a novice wrestler compared to Tamina - has already battled Naomi for the Smackdown Women's Championship.\n\nWhen Lana suggested that it's because nobody fears Tamina, many expected the Ravishing Russian to be obliterated by her ally.\n\nHowever, Lana claimed that she can help Tamina crush her competitors if she follows her instructions, which would eventually make her Champion - though it remains to be seen just what Lana has planned for Tamina moving forward.\n\n4. Randy Orton gives Rusev a taste of his own medicine\n\nAfter surprising Randy Orton at the end of last week's Smackdown with a Superkick out of nowhere, Rusev was back in action this week as he again took on Chad Gable, ahead of facing Orton at Summerslam.\n\nGable had sent Rusev to the outside with a belly-to-belly suplex, but when they roamed outside, Rusev threw Gable into the commentary table to ensure that both men were counted out in a draw before locking in the Accolade submission on Gable.\n\nHaving left Gable in a crumpled heap, Rusev returned to the ring to address the crowd, only to be hit with an RKO - yes, out of nowhere - from Orton, who had stormed the ring to give the Bulgarian Brute a taste of his own medicine.\n\n5. This time, it's Kevin Owens who accidentally attacks Shane McMahon\n\nWith Kevin Owens bidding to reclaim the United States Championship, he attempted to turn Champion AJ Styles and guest referee Shane McMahon against each - and it seemed to work when Styles accidentally hit McMahon with a Pele Kick after an altercation with Owens.\n\nStyles attempted to apologise to McMahon this week, and whilst Shane claimed there was no need to apologise, he did warn Styles that if he puts his hands on him at Summerslam, he will get just as physical with him in retaliation.\n\nOwens gleefully marched down to the ring to bask in frayed relations between Styles and McMahon, but after an attempted handshake with Styles sparked a shoving match, Owens hit McMahon square in the face with a Superkick.\n\nThat means that both men have now accidentally taken out the guest referee ahead of their match on Sunday, adding real intrigue to how McMahon will call the match.\n\n6. The Usos defeat The New Day ahead of Summerslam bout\n\nHaving lost their Smackdown Tag Team Championships at Battleground in an excellent match, The Usos will face off against The New Day at Summerslam in a bid to win back their titles from Big E, Kofi Kingston and Xavier Woods.\n\nThe two teams have gone back and forth in recent weeks, and The Usos now have momentum heading into Sunday's match having picked up a win over Kofi and Xavier - now they just have to do it again in Brooklyn on Sunday to reclaim the Smackdown Tag Team Championships once again.\n\n7. Baron Corbin loses after cashing in his Money in the Bank contract\n\nAfter opening the show, Jinder Mahal also closed the show by taking on John Cena, and he even had The Singh Brothers helping him yet again before referee Mike Chioda banished both men from ringside.\n\nThat left Mahal one on one with Cena, and Cena appeared to be in position for the win after hitting a huge Avalance Attitude Adjustment from the second rope, his opponent at Summerslam - Baron Corbin - ran in to break up his pin attempt and leave the match as a no-contest.\n\nAfter hitting Cena with his Money in the Bank briefcase, Corbin turned back from the ramp to the ring and cashed in his contract, but that proved to be a huge mistake.\n\nUpon hearing the bell for his match with Mahal, Corbin turned to knock Cena off the apron, giving Mahal the perfect opportunity to swoop in and roll up Corbin for the three count, retaining his WWE Championship and leaving Corbin to rue his missed opportunity - {"id": "9784546", "categories": [{"id": 114, "label": "dmoz/Arts/Performing Arts/Theatre", "uri": "dmoz/Arts/Performing_Arts/Theatre", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 286, "label": "dmoz/Society/History/By Time Period", "uri": "dmoz/Society/History/By_Time_Period", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 362, "label": "dmoz/Recreation/Guns/Competition Shooting", "uri": "dmoz/Recreation/Guns/Competition_Shooting", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-17", "uri": "711135157", "source": {"id": "4", "title": "ESPN.com", "uri": "espn.com"}, "url": "http://www.espn.com/wwe/story/_/id/20362993", "body": "SummerSlam week has finally arrived, with the WWE set to take over Brooklyn's Barclays Center for four days of festivities.\n\nThe supershow card, featuring stars from both Raw and SmackDown, features the culmination of several key rivalries and, in all likelihood, will plant the seeds for several storylines that won't play out entirely until next year's WrestleMania.\n\nWith that in mind, we're breaking down every match on the SummerSlam card, with a particular focus on the two major titles on each show -- the Universal championship, Raw women's championship, WWE championship and SmackDown women's championship.\n\nPaul Heyman promised that he and Lesnar will leave the WWE should Lesnar lose. That possibility hangs like a giant axe over this match. But the energy and excitement for this Universal championship match didn't begin just a few weeks ago. No, the path to this Fatal 4-Way is a long, intertwined patchwork involving all four participants, with significant history dating back to early 2015. There's animosity going in every single direction between these four behemoths in the ring, but the central conflict in the middle of it all is Reigns vs. Lesnar, and the unfinished business they have with one another.\n\nLet's take it back to January 2015 when Reigns won the Royal Rumble and got booed out of Philadelphia's Wells Fargo Center despite The Rock raising his arm at the close of the show. The build-up to the WrestleMania 31 match between Reigns and then-WWE champion Lesnar was, at best, polarizing and controversial. A lot of fans in Santa Clara seemed poised to boo Reigns out of Levi's Stadium too, until Seth Rollins did the unthinkable and cashed in his Money in the Bank briefcase mid-main event, stealing the title away.\n\nBoth Lesnar and Reigns were in a triple-threat WWE championship No. 1 contenders match in 2016 featuring Dean Ambrose (won by Reigns) and both men were in the last two Royal Rumbles, but there hasn't been a clash of this magnitude since their spoiled match at WrestleMania 31. Rumors abound of a future one-on-one match, but for the time being, this Fatal 4-Way offers far more permutations.\n\nReigns has history with the other two participants in this match as well. In Samoa Joe's first match on the main roster, Joe beat Reigns on Monday Night Raw in February -- and Joe got the better of Reigns twice more in June; Joe won a Fatal 5-Way at Extreme Rules that earned him a shot at Lesnar and the Universal title at Great Balls of Fire, and then beat Reigns again two weeks later on Raw. Their Universal title No. 1 contender's match in mid-July ended in a no contest after Braun Strowman returned, which was the main catalyst for this four-way.\n\nThe brightest and most intense animosity hangs between Strowman and Reigns, who have had several of the most intense WWE matches of the year thus far. They faced off as far back as October 2015, when Reigns was the first to defeat Strowman (via countout) in the midst of the Wyatt Family vs. The Shield rivalry, but this rivalry was truly ignited at Fastlane this past March.\n\nReigns gave Strowman his first pinfall loss in the WWE, and Strowman hasn't stopped chasing him ever since. Strowman pushed Reigns off a loading dock while he was strapped to a stretcher and tipped over the ambulance he was put inside. Reigns backed an ambulance up at high speed into a trailer a few months later. And still, Strowman wasn't finished with Reigns quite yet.\n\nBetween the history and animosity among all those combinations, there's more than enough heat to go around. Add in the unknown of Lesnar vs. Strowman and Joe vs. Strowman, and there's a lot to work with here. Without having to rely simply on himself to get through this match, this main event can carry on far longer than your average Lesnar match as well, if need be.\n\nIt seems unlikely that Lesnar walks out without the title and walks out of WWE again, but if the last couple of years have taught us anything, it's that the WWE isn't afraid to take a big chance. One year after the Barclays Center crowd inexplicably and loudly booed the design and color of the new Universal championship, taking away from a big moment for Rollins and Finn Balor, this match will be a far more popular spectacle.\n\nNo words necessary. Just a SPEAR from @WWERomanReigns! #RAW #SummerSlam pic.twitter.com/qCEdQEcU09\n\n- WWE (@WWE) August 15, 2017\n\n\"That's going to be a pretty interesting situation. I can't recall a time where you had four guys all sort of having this monster build, all in the same way.\"\n\n\"Brock Lesnar is Brock Lensar. You don't need to say more than that.\"\n\n\"Roman Reigns, whether people love him or hate him ... he's the guy.\"\n\n\"Samoa Joe, since he's come to WWE, has just become this unstoppable force with his match with Lesnar, and taking Lesnar as far as he did, and what he's done with Roman and Braun.\"\n\n\"Then there's Braun Strowman who has very quickly become this, he calls himself the monster among men, and it's hard to argue that he isn't when you talk about a guy with that size and that level of strength, but that when you see him run across the ring and the speed at which he does it, his ability to throw guys around, I hate to say it because it's a different style, but it's almost Lesnar-eqsque, seeing a guy that big... trust me, when you're in a ring with a guy and he's that size, he's not supposed to be able to move that fast. And that's the way you feel like when you're in the ring with Lesnar.\"\n\n\"Add into that the Jon Jones challenge and everything else, Lesnar doesn't have to get beat here. If he just doesn't win, that's all that matters. It's a really cool dynamic that you don't know what is going to happen.\"\n\n\"You have four guys in there, all over the 260 mark, everybody in there is agile, and can move, and is fast. These are athletes. These aren't plodding guys lumbering around the ring. This is speed and quickness. They move like cruiserweights, but they're not. It's a whole new world, in that manner.\"\n\nAfter a lengthy absence post-WrestleMania, Lesnar and Heyman have settled right back into the pocket over the last month or so. Getting into the ring with guys his own size gives Lesnar a lot more to work with, and with three of them in play, expect to see some vintage Lesnar (sorry Michael Cole).\n\nAs much as the talk about a Lesnar-Jon Jones UFC superfight has grown legs, and seems especially likely in a world where Mayweather-McGregor is a reality, Lesnar still has several months of his previous USADA suspension to serve out before he can even think of stepping back into the octagon. That fight will happen, but emerging from this match with a new rival (or an old one) and starting his path to the WrestleMania 34 main event seems the likeliest scenario in this match.\n\nStrowman seems like the least likely to emerge from this match as Universal champion, if for the simple fact that he doesn't really need a world title right now. A strong showing in this match would be a perfectly acceptable outcome, and if it sets the stage for a future one-on-one match with Lesnar some time between now and WrestleMania, all the better.\n\nIf, somehow, he emerges victorious here, it's hard to imagine a scenario where anyone outside of this quartet (most likely Reigns) could take that title off of him. Strowman's grown by leaps and bounds over the last year, and he can go with any of the top guys on Raw right now. It simply feels like he needs to get a few more big matches under his belt (and this one could go a long way) before he becomes the top guy on Raw.\n\nThe Brooklyn crowd, at its very best, can be described as impatient over the last few years. A Reigns victory would likely end with a showering of boos and a lot of the same old arguments being made against \"the big dog\". While I, for one, have heard the words \"dog\" and \"yard\" enough for two lifetimes, the Reigns hate overall has grown tired. As long as there's a creative end-game in play, with Lesnar perhaps coming back at Royal Rumble or WrestleMania, there's no reason Reigns can't leave this match as the winner.\n\nThe conflict with Strowman still seems to have a little bit of fire underneath it, and with Strowman and Joe sticking around to chase him in Lesnar's absence, there are plenty of ways things could play out in the last few months of 2017 with Reigns on top.\n\nAfter a bit of bad luck and some uncertainty at the very beginning of his main roster run, Samoa Joe has turned it up to 11 in his chase of Lesnar and the Universal championship. He pushed the champ hard at Great Balls of Fire, and everything leading up to and after that event screams of Joe being a long-time fixture in the main event.\n\nA win for Joe would come as something of a shock on Sunday, but there's no doubt he's done everything right to get himself to the spot he's in right now. If something screwy happens, like a Paul Heyman double-cross that I'm not sure WWE's in a position to pull off at this moment, Joe could do a lot of good carrying the title into the fall.\n\nBoth Strowman and Samoa Joe will be competing at their first SummerSlam. Only two superstars in WWE history have won a world title in their SummerSlam debut. Lesnar defeated The Rock for the WWE Championship in 2002, and Balor defeated Rollins to become the inaugural Universal champion in 2016. He decimated John Cena in 2014 when he made him look like a rag doll via German suplexes and became champion in one of the most lopsided victories in recent history.\n\nIf you see Brock Lesnar at SummerSlam this year, you might not see that. In fact, you might just see him leave.\n\nThat's because if Lesnar loses the Fatal Four Way main event and the Universal Championship, he will leave WWE. And some signs point to that actually happening instead of just being a story line bluff. Minutes after defeating Daniel Cormier at UFC 214, Jon Jones got a mic and turned his attention to Lesnar, who was last seen in the UFC in 2016.:\n\n\"Brock Lesnar, if you wanna know what it feels like to get your ass kicked by a guy who weighs 40 pounds less than you, meet me in the octagon.\"\n\nTwo days later, WWE capitalized on that hype. Paul Heyman went out to paint the champ as the ultimate underdog, one whose challenges may be so difficult that he doesn't actually overcome them. He blamed it on the odds of winning the Fatal Four Way title match. With Roman Reigns, Samoa Joe, and Braun Strowman making up three quarters of the large adult wrestling sons match, defeating them seems like a lofty goal from the start.\n\nHeyman expanded a bit more and blamed the match's existence on who Kurt Angle answers to, implying that its less of a story motive and one commanded by WWE's real-life bosses. \"Why don't we just rename this SummerSlam 2017: Brock Loses the Universal Title. Because sir, respectfully, you've been told to make Brock Lesnar pay the ultimate price haven't you?\" If the nod to UFC wasn't enough Heyman spelled out what fighting fans wanted to hear. If Brock loses the Universal Title at SummerSlam, he leaves WWE.\n\nJust a week before, reports came out that Lesnar would not sign an extension with WWE, so this makes perfect sense. Would Lesnar leave WWE early to un-retire from the UFC? Not necessarily, although this is may be the best way to inject a sense of doubt in spite of Brock's victorious performances at SummerSlams past.\n\nTaking a look at his opponents, one would have to wonder if Lesnar could legitimately lose. The competition has never been more prepared to topple Brock.\n\nLesnar and Roman Reigns faced off in the main event of WrestleMania 31. Both competitors were spent as the match wound down, giving Seth Rollins his chance to cash in his Money in the Bank briefcase and snatch the WWE Championship from Brock. Had the one-on-one match continued, Reigns could have beaten Lesnar -- that's not something many Lesnar opponents get to even entertain.\n\nMost recently, Samoa Joe got his chance at the Universal strap. Joe got the best of him with enough sleeper holds to make Lesnar look like the ripest tomato in the garden. But thanks to a quick escape via F5, Lesnar was able to scratch out the win. The moral victory that Joe got from having an entertaining match with Lesnar despite losing may have been worth more than the actual match's victory. Joe should have beaten Lesnar, but it was last gasp vs. last gasp, and Brock's won out.\n\nThen you have Braun Strowman, the comparative novice in the match, who removes a certain characteristic from most Lesnar matches -- the size advantage. Lesnar must look up at his opponent and cower (well, the Lesnar eqvivalent of cowering) at the sight of WWE's monster among men. Their singular confrontation was teased, however, during last Monday's edition of RAW. Surrounded by rows of security guards (and after Roman and Joe were taken out) Lesnar and Strowman had an intense staredown that escalated into a fight, much to the chagrin of the men with their tucked in black tees and then the entire WWE locker room.\n\nLooking back, you could see this as a pivotal moment within the super heavyweight portion of the WWE roster. Strowman winning at SummerSlam could be a changing of the guard, officially certifying him as WWE's top beast.\n\nUnlike most of his other SummerSlam appearances, Brock doesn't have to be pinned to lose in this multi-man match -- that's how he ended up dropping the title to Rollins back at Mania 31, as Seth pinned Roman instead of Lesnar. Brock Lesnar's beast incarnate persona would not suffer as a result, which would come in handy upon Lesnar's next quarterly set of appearances. With WWE on hold, he could take that time for a UFC fight.\n\nWith a wrestler as dominant as Brock Lesnar in the venue he's most dominant in, it's hard to convince fans he has a legitimate chance of losing. But thanks to his large competition, and the possibility of fighting in the octagon again, WWE has done just that.\n\nStill, it's feasible to see Lesnar win at SummerSlam and fight in the UFC: He did it just last year. {"id": "10058553", "categories": [{"id": 115, "label": "dmoz/Society/People", "uri": "dmoz/Society/People", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 360, "label": "dmoz/Society/Lifestyle Choices", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Lifestyle_Choices", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 399, "label": "dmoz/Sports/Golf/Tournaments and Events", "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Golf/Tournaments_and_Events", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 1089, "label": "dmoz/Arts/Music/Clubs and Venues", "uri": "dmoz/Arts/Music/Clubs_and_Venues", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 1184, "label": "dmoz/Sports/Wrestling/Professional", "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Wrestling/Professional", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 1230, "label": "dmoz/Society/Lifestyle Choices/Vegetarianism", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Lifestyle_Choices/Vegetarianism", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 1318, "label": "dmoz/Business/Textiles and Nonwovens/Fibers", "uri": "dmoz/Business/Textiles_and_Nonwovens/Fibers", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-19", "uri": "711900485", "source": {"id": "3441", "title": "The Independent", "uri": "independent.co.uk"}, "url": "http://www.independent.co.uk/sport/general/wwe-mma-wrestling/wwe-summerslam-brock-lesnar-samoa-joe-roman-reigns-braun-strowman-demon-finn-balor-bray-wyatt-a7901851.html", "body": "WWE's Raw stars have laid out their stall for SummerSlam this coming weekend with Brock Lesnar set to defend his Universal Championship in a mammoth main event.\n\nSummerSlam is one of just a few annual events held by WWE to feature both the Raw and Smackdown rosters together, and the red brand has done all it can to ensure they live up to their end of the bargain of putting on a spectacle to remember on Sunday night.\n\nLesnar's latest defence of the Universal Championship could possibly be his last for a while, too.\n\nThe former UFC star works a part time schedule for the company and has threatened in this latest storyline to leave should be dethroned at SummerSlam, out of protest in part to being made to put his gold on the line against three other combatants in Roman Reigns, Samoa Joe and Braun Strowman. Lesnar wouldn't have to be involved in the decisive end to the match to lose the championship - so a lengthy absence following that kind of 'loss' seems the perfect way to keep his monstrous reputation in tact while he takes off for a while.\n\nIf that does indeed prove to be the case - and it's far from certain - the matter then becomes a question of just who WWE decides to crown as a new champion for now. Lesnar and Reigns are still rumoured to be on course for a WrestleMania event next year so the prospect of Joe or Strowman taking the title seems more likely.\n\nOne thing's for sure, Sunday's match probably won't be a long one. This foursome have produced some great television over the last few weeks by essentially just battering one another - as four big, powerful athletes it works well enough.\n\nRead more Why you should not miss WWE NXT Takeover Brooklyn III\n\nAnother highlight for Raw's portion of SummerSlam is the reuniting, albeit a little tenuously, of former Shield teammates Seth Rollins and Dean Ambrose. A partnership between the two has been heavily teased in recent weeks and this week's episode of Raw saw it confirmed that they will in fact pair up to take on the Raw tag team champions in Cesaro and Sheamus. It seems inevitable that, sooner or later, the combustible pairing of Rollins and Ambrose will become unlikely champions - is SummerSlam a little too soon?\n\nA year after winning the Universal championship on a bittersweet night at SummerSlam 2016, Finn Balor is set to go head to head with Bray Wyatt in Brooklyn this weekend. Balor won the gold twelve months ago but was forced to vacate it immediately after a legitimate injury sustained in the process kept him on the shelf for the better part of the next nine months. The programme with Wyatt has probably been Balor's best since his return and, to further whet the appetite, it was even confirmed on Raw this week that his hugely popular demon persona will make its return at the weekend. It's an entrance usually worth paying for on its own.\n\nFinn Balor will return in his Demon persona to try and get the better of Bray Wyatt (WWE)\n\nBig Cass has gone it alone in WWE after distancing himself from former partner Enzo. At SummerSlam he faces Big Show in a match that sees Enzo suspended above the ring in a shark cage. This probably needs to be where WWE draws a line under Enzo and Cass on screen. If Cass is to make it big then he'll need to truly move on to something new, while Enzo's energy and popularity will see him do well enough in whatever follows for him. As for SummerSlam - it's only right that Cass is left standing tall at the end but it won't be plain sailing against the veteran giant.\n\nThe Raw women's championship is also on the line at SummerSlam. A win for Sasha Banks against Nia Jaxx this week puts her in the spotlight on Sunday as she goes up against Alexa Bliss. An unfortunate injury to previous challenger Bayley has unwittingly set us up for the possibility of a fascinating story here; could Banks go on to claim the gold having stepped in at the expense of her good friend? If so, it'd be a great opportunity for a bitter Bayley to come back and claim a measure of revenge - quite whether WWE is prepared to do that given the her huge popularity with the younger members of their fan base remains to be seen. Either way, it sets things up nicely for SummerSlam.\n\nAlexa Bliss defends her Raw Women's Championship against Sasha Banks (WWE)\n\nThat's not the final Raw title being defended at the weekend. Akira Tozawa sprang a huge surprise in winning the Cruiserweight championship on this week's episode of Raw. The scheduled match with previous champ Neville at SummerSlam still goes ahead with the roles of champ and challenger now reversed - after losing the gold following a record reign of almost 200 days, Brit Neville will be hungry for revenge as he bids for an immediate return to championship glory.\n\nSummerSlam is recognised as second only to WrestleMania in terms of WWE events during the year - there's no surprise that this stacked card has that marquee-event feel to it. Raw has done its bit to get us ready - it's now over to Smackdown Live to see what they have in store...\n\nWWE Summerslam is live this Sunday as a four-hour special from Brooklyn, New York. Watch live on WWE Network - head to wwe.com for more details.\n\nMore about: WWE SummerSlam Brock Lesnar Roman Reigns Braun Strowman Samoa Joe Finn Balor Bray Wyatt Reuse content", "dateTime": It's this type of booking that can only be described as \"backwards\" which is also destructive, doesn't make any sense and does little-to-nothing for anyone involved. More importantly, it hurts the very delicate WWE championship reign of Jinder Mahal.\n\nI wrote about Jinder Mahal's title run (here) a couple of weeks ago. Instead of putting a fresh foot forward with their surprise World champion; they've sent him out on TV to cut the same promos and same match finishes with the same opponent month after month. From all reports he has had good matches and has had heat from the live crowds at house shows. So there's clearly just a problem when it comes to TV, it's the same over and over again. I don't even know who to blame for this either. The blame has to go somewhere and I refuse to put it on Mahal.\n\nIn the WWE, there's four guys who seem to have long-term booking plans. You can figure out who they are, just turn on Monday night RAW, all the answers are there. When it comes to the rest of the roster, \"close your eyes and throw the dart\" seems to be the booking technique. There seems to be no planning outside of the current month they're in. We are a week away from the second biggest show of the year and the WWE champion got his opponent nineteen days before the show. Not to mention how we got there, they put two guys against each other on a Tuesday and the winner is in. The booking isn't only backwards, it's tired.\n\nWhere's the build? Where's Shinsuke Nakamura's rise to the title shot? He was just working Baron Corbin in quite possibly the worst matches of his career. Coming off the heels of the unbelievably uneventful program with Corbin, he's thrown in a match with John Cena for a SummerSlam title shot. There's no build, doesn't spike the rating at all, and with the exception of the last minute, wasn't great. There needs to be build to raise ratings, to get people invested to tune in. People tuned in to see the horrible payoff of the Kurt Angle storyline because it was built up over several weeks. The way they booked Nakamura into this match with Mahal is another example of how they've screwed up Mahal's title run.\n\nThis past Tuesday, we had the pleasure of getting the Randy Orton vs Jinder Mahal \"Grudge match\". The title wasn't on the line, and they made the point to beat the \"Singh brothers are not here\" (THEY WERE THERE!) into our heads. It had disaster for Mahal written all over it. You could see it coming from a mile away. In the middle of the ring, in their best match yet, Orton beat Mahal. The WWE champion loses on TV. In what world does this seem like a good idea? I watched this match (hours after it aired) with a couple of longtime wrestling fans who couldn't believe it either. I ranted on Twitter (tweet me) and some of the responses I got proved that the WWE backwards booking had poisoned the fans.\n\n@RealCJLive: Yes because losing once out of the 4 times he's faced Orton is a joke. Get over it.\n\nWell, him beating Orton three times has done NOTHING, so losing to him in the \"Grudge match\" certainly will do NOTHING for the CHAMPION.\n\n@JayAlletto: The entire point was to close the door definitively on that feud & launch Orton vs Rusev.\n\nNo. First of all, Orton and Mahal have both moved on already. Mahal has a new opponent at SummerSlam (they've had NO interaction), as does Orton. The Mahal/Orton match wasn't done to launch the Rusev feud, Rusev kicking him as the show went off the air was. Which could've been done a million and one other ways. The champ didn't need to lose on TV for that kick to happen.\n\n@RealCJLive: I've never seen someone this mad over one loss lol\n\nThen you must not pay attention to wrestling fans on Reddit or Twitter. The WWE champion, no matter who it is, should NOT lose on TV in a singles match unless he's dropping the belt! I don't even think he should get pinned in a tag match but that's a lot better than a singles match. So this was more of the straw that broke the camel's back as it pertains to this Mahal title run. The guy can't even win on TV when his help isn't there. Ugh.\n\nThen I got a tweet from @mkurtz91 that gave me hope: I'm with you Brian. Building a credible champion whether they are heel or face is vital. Credibility makes for more money matches.\n\nDid Randy Orton, a thirteen time WWE champion, need to beat Jinder Mahal? Absolutely not. Does beating Jinder Mahal do anything for Orton moving forward? Absolutely not. Shouldn't these questions be asked before you make the decision to have your champion lose on TV? Absolutely yes. Wouldn't Orton beating Mahal technically make him the number one contender now? Yes, yes it would. It's just illogical that the guy who didn't win the title, didn't win the feud, gets the last win of the program. WHAT? If Orton absolutely, no way around it needed to pin Mahal in this program (which he didn't), he should've done it before Mahal became champion. It's backwards booking and it's become the WWE way, the way it shouldn't be. {"id": "9900628", "categories": [{"id": 7, "label": "dmoz/Arts", "uri": "dmoz/Arts", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 651, "label": "dmoz/Society/Disabled/Arts", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Disabled/Arts", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 896, "label": "dmoz/Sports/Martial Arts", "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Martial_Arts", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 947, "label": "dmoz/Business/Employment/Careers", "uri": "dmoz/Business/Employment/Careers", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 1058, "label": "dmoz/Recreation/Collecting/Toys", "uri": "dmoz/Recreation/Collecting/Toys", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 1379, "label": "dmoz/Sports/Martial Arts/Jujutsu", "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Martial_Arts/Jujutsu", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 1413, "label": "dmoz/Shopping/Sports/Martial Arts", "uri": "dmoz/Shopping/Sports/Martial_Arts", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 1620, "label": "dmoz/Sports/Martial Arts/Schools and Instruction", "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Martial_Arts/Schools_and_Instruction", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-18", "uri": "711459055", "source": {"id": "3", "title": "Rolling Stone", "uri": "rollingstone.com"}, "url": "http://www.rollingstone.com/sports/features/wwe-summerslam-samoa-joe-battles-brock-lesnar-for-universal-title-w498362", "body": "Wrestler plans to make the most of what is arguably the biggest opportunity of his career on Sunday\n\nOver the past decade, Samoa Joe has been on of the most revered wrestlers outside the WWE. The 38-year-old finally made his main roster debut in January, and less than seven months later, he is gearing up to headline one of the organization's biggest events of the year. Joe, along with Roman Reigns and Braun Strowman, will challenge WWE Universal Champion Brock Lesnar for the title in an anticipated fatal four-way at SummerSlam, which goes down at Barclays Center in Brooklyn on Sunday, and streams live on the WWE Network.\n\nIt's a dream opportunity for an athlete who has worked tirelessly to reach the pinnacle of his industry. Joe says he doesn't plan on wasting his chance.\n\n\"Six months in, I'm in the main event of SummerSlam, and my prospects beyond that look pretty good,\" Joe tells Rolling Stone. \"I absolutely did not know that I would not be in this spot right now, but I did know I would have the opportunity to make my spot in this match. When the opportunity was presented to me, I took full advantage of it and I find myself here now. ... Sometimes you've just got to knock on the door and keep knocking until they can't deny you and they let you in. Here I am.\"\n\nAlthough there was some moments where it seemed Joe's shot at WWE glory would never arrive, it eventually did, and he's maximized nearly every moment. His recent feud with Lesnar has captured the praise of fans and proved to any remaining doubters that he's more than capable of holding his own when the lights shine brightest.\n\nJoe got a chance to challenge Lesnar one-on-one for the title at WWE Great Balls of Fire in July, but after a highly physical encounter, he succumbed to \"The Beast\" and his trademark F-5 finisher. He will have two other men standing in his way when he takes his second crack at the belt, but regardless of the outcome, Joe hopes to battle with the former UFC Heavyweight champion Lesnar many more times in the future.\n\n\"The program with Brock, I'd love to explore it more and have many more encounters with Brock across the pay-per-view scale,\" Joe says. \"I think in general the build and everything going into this has been something that's peaked the interest of the general audience. Ratings are up, we are definitely drawing interest for the show.\"\n\nJoe feels he meshes well with Lesnar in the ring, and that's partially due to the fact both have hard-hitting styles that stem from martial arts backgrounds.\n\n\"People understand the simplicity of violence and martial arts has always been about the more efficient way to deliver said violence upon an adversary,\" Joe says. \"I've kept that philosophy as the focal point of what I do. ... Martial arts in general definitely influenced my style. I was a judo player as a kid and I think a lot of the concepts in judo as a kid played over. It influenced my style and has been a center point of what I do.\"\n\nJoe believes that his nearly 18 years in the industry has prepared him to deliver some of his best work at SummerSlam. It won't be an easy challenge to produce a match that meets the standards of everyone watching, but he holds strong faith in his ability to hold up his end of the bargain.\n\n\"As long as you're confident in your skill set and what you can do, you're usually good to go,\" Joe says. \"What I am capable of has got me very far thus far, so there's no real change to the game plan. I'll be able to go in there, and I know what I do. I know what I do well and I know what I can do with other people. It's all those factors in maintaining self-confidence and knowing that expectations are high and you've got to go in there and exceed those at the show.\"\n\nOver a long and prestigious career, Joe's seen and done almost everything in the sport. Winning a major championship under the WWE banner has eluded him, but SummerSlam presents a realistic chance to fill the missing gap on his resume.\n\nWhether Joe will be able to dethrone Lesnar, while also overcoming two of the most physically imposing members of the WWE roster in Reigns and Strowman, remains to be seen. Joe, however, feels he's ready to take on the responsibility that comes with carrying the Universal Championship.\n\n\"Going into SummerSlam, I go against some of the most accomplished performers in the world today and some of the hottest,\" Joe says. \"When you got guys in there like Brock Lesnar, Roman Reigns, Braun Strowman - these are competitors which have the tendency to push their opponents to greater heights and great accolades. I hope the intensity will carry over and we'll deliver something spectacular.\n\n\"It's one of the biggest opportunities of my career without a doubt. Six months and this is my second shot at the Universal Championship. To add that to my resume and check that box amongst the accolades, it means a very great deal to me.\"", "dateTime": "2017-08-18T13:15:00Z", "extractedDates": null, "sim": 0.7176470756530762, {"id": "9183804", "categories": [{"id": 111, "label": "dmoz/Arts/Television", "uri": "dmoz/Arts/Television", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 212, "label": "dmoz/Arts/Television/Programs", "uri": "dmoz/Arts/Television/Programs", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 286, "label": "dmoz/Society/History/By Time Period", "uri": "dmoz/Society/History/By_Time_Period", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 347, "label": "dmoz/Shopping/Toys and Games/Trading Cards", "uri": "dmoz/Shopping/Toys_and_Games/Trading_Cards", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 561, "label": "dmoz/Games/Video Games/Sports", "uri": "dmoz/Games/Video_Games/Sports", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 596, "label": "dmoz/Arts/Radio/Formats", "uri": "dmoz/Arts/Radio/Formats", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 1055, "label": "dmoz/Sports/Wrestling", "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Wrestling", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 1056, "label": "dmoz/Sports/Wrestling/Amateur", "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Wrestling/Amateur", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 1184, "label": "dmoz/Sports/Wrestling/Professional", "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Wrestling/Professional", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-14", "uri": "709506617", "source": {"id": "2187", "title": "Cageside Seats", "uri": "cagesideseats.com"}, "url": "https://www.cagesideseats.com/2017/8/14/16144548/5-matches-wwe-should-have-booked-for-summerslam", "body": "On Sunday the 20th of August, WWE is storming its way to Brooklyn. With a tremendous roster on board and a huge main event, Summerslam 2017 is shaping up to be one of WWE's biggest PPVs in recent memory.\n\nLast year's Summerslam was the first PPV since WWE took a big risk and reinforced the brand extension. Yet a lot of things have changed between then and now. WWE choosing last year's main event to be Brock Lesnar vs Randy Orton showed that even after the brand extension WWE still relied heavily on its veterans and had little faith in the new stars. This year, while Brock Lesnar will be in the main event once again, two fresh faces will now join him in Samoa Joe and Braun Strowman. With Roman Reigns also on that battlefield, this match promises to be a hell of a slugfest.\n\nWhat's especially intriguing about that match is that it wasn't made a Fatal 4 Way just because there wasn't anything else to do. This year WWE has taken to a lot of multi-man/woman matches simply because they couldn't come up with anything creative for some wrestlers. We've seen that bring a lot of damage to Smackdown's women's division. However, that isn't the case with the Universal championship match at Summerslam. The characters of each participant in the match are very well-defined and each of them has huge momentum. That has simply created a situation where no singles match between any of the four competitors can be as entertaining and colossal as the four men battling each other in the same ring at the same time.\n\nSummerslam will also feature Shinsuke Nakamura, who has been one of the hottest names in all of wrestling for many years, challenge for the WWE Championship for the first time ever.\n\nAdd to that the exciting drama between Seth Rollins and Dean Ambrose and them most probably challenging Sheamus and Cesaro for the RAW Tag Team Championship, AJ Styles defending the US Championship against Kevin Owens with Shane McMahon as a referee, and John Cena vs Baron Corbin and you have an almost flawless show in Summerslam.\n\nThe reason almost was used there is because of the relatively weak midcard, particularly on the Smackdown Live side of things. As mentioned above, WWE currently has one of its strongest, if not indeed its strongest, roster ever. However, WWE is snubbing some of the roster's most talented wrestlers of chances to shine on Summerslam's huge stage.\n\nThere is always the 'there is only so much space on the card' argument and that is where this fan decides to step in. There are some modifications that WWE could have done to the card to present its roster with better chances. These modifications are yours truly's 5 Matches WWE Should Have Booked for Summerslam.\n\n1- 20 Man Battle Royal (Winner gets a championship opportunity of his choosing with 10 RAW and 10 Smackdown Live superstars)\n\nAdmittedly, a Battle Royal is not the most exciting match to book. However, with both RAW and\n\nSmackdown wrestlers in the same ring and a title shot hanging in the balance, the match should feel much more significant. The title shot also doesn't have to be on the winner's show so it's also a chance for wrestlers to switch brands.\n\nRAW participants: Jeff Hardy, Matt Hardy, Apollo Crews, Kalisto, Elias, Bo Dallas, Curtis Axel, Heath Slater, Rhyno, and Cedric Alexander.\n\nSmackdown participants: Rusev, Luke Harper, Tye Dillinger, Erick Rowan, Aiden English, Mike Kanellis, Mojo Rawley, Zack Ryder, James Ellsworth, and a returning Kane.\n\nA win here could do wonders for guys like Rusev, Harper, and Crews. It may seem controversial that talents such as the Hardy Boyz do a Battle Royal. But with The Revival out of the picture, being featured in the Battle Royal would be better than facing off against momentum-less Gallows and Anderson. It would give both of them shots at single runs which is something that lots of fans have been asking for.\n\nEven though he's been getting lesser spotlight than his former partner Jason Jordan has, Chad Gable has been making the most out all of the opportunities he's received thus far. Someone who hasn't had any spotlight on him for a while though is Dolph Ziggler, who hasn't been on TV for over a month. A feud between these two would produce wrestling goodness.\n\nThe feud could have started with Dolph interrupting a Gable promo and admitting that Gable is immensely skilled but that he would go nowhere because he isn't the corporate's guys' kind of star. Dolph tells him that he had been there before himself and recalls every time he got pushed down by the machine. Gable tells him that he's just making up excuses for his own failure. Dolph gets livid and mercilessly assaults Gable. Gable then vows to get his revenge at Summerslam.\n\n3- Becky Lynch & Charlotte Flair vs Peyton Royce & Billie Kay\n\nBooking Natalya verus Naomi for the Smackdown Women's Championship at Summerslam isn't a bad decision. Natalya is long time veteran who can give the glowing babyface her toughest challenge yet and make her look great during the process. Though, not having Becky Lynch and Charlotte on the card is unfair to them and also an illogical decision, given their big star power.\n\nNXT's Iconic Duo haven't been doing much on NXT either. They have both already gotten multiple shots at Asuka and lost. They have now simply been relegated to being shown on backstage skits that serve to showcase other NXT talents. Their stint at Full Sail should've been over by now.\n\nThe road to Summerslam would have been a perfect opportunity to call Royce and Kay up to the main roster. And putting them against another team of best friends like Charlotte and Becky would show how cohesive they are together and help them establish a reign of dominance on Smackdown Live.\n\nThe UK wrestling scene has been producing some of the best in ring action this year. That's in large part thanks to WWE UK and Progress World Champion Pete Dunne. He's been extraordinary everywhere he's been from Progress to OTT.\n\nWWE's Cruiserweight division hasn't been on such a hot track. Neville is currently the only credible cruiserweight in WWE. No challenger at this point feels like he's worthy of beating Neville, producing a stalemate on WWE's 205 Live.\n\nPete Dunne could crash through the 205 Live roster and call them out for being weak. It wouldn't be long before Neville takes offense to Pete Dunne's actions. Neville fights back against Dunne and says that maybe the rest of the cruiserweights are not as competent as he is but he will continue to defend his kingdom. He challenges Pete Dunne to a match at Summerslam. Dunne accepts but says that he doesn't want to challenge for the Cruiserweight championship because being a champion of that division would only bring him shame. The two agree that the loser of the match would have to admit inferiority to the winner.\n\nThe match would have been a huge way for WWE to give its UK division much needed exposure after the promised weekly WWE Network show was delayed indefinitely. And it would have definitely been a much more heated match than the Neville vs Akira Tozawa rematch.\n\nThe biggest mistake fans won't forgive WWE for is not having Sami Zayn on the Summerslam card. Last year, WWE put him in an odd tag team match with Neville versus the Dudley Boyz on the Kickoff show and it looks like Sami will be in another throwaway bout on the Kickoff show again if he actually finds his way to Brooklyn this year at all.\n\nSami's career on the main roster thus far has been highlighted by weak inconsistent booking with his only two major moments being his victory over Kevin Owens at Battleground and surviving against Braun Strowman at Roadblock. Both of these moments were never capitalized on.\n\nRusev vs Randy Orton is also a mistake because at this point because neither of them can afford a loss. Rusev just made his much anticipated comeback last month only to be featured in an overdone feud that served to keep John Cena busy. Orton is just off a long rivalry with WWE Champion Jinder Mahal that hasn't done him any favors due to WWE portraying it as a USA vs India rivalry. Randy is not the kind of babyface that comes off as patriotic and quite frankly his best work has never been as a babyface. That's why his next feud shouldn't have been against a heel; not to mention, a heel who has been getting cheered for the past two years like Rusev. Orton's next feud should have set him up to turn heel again. And there's no better rival for that predicament than Sami Zayn.\n\nThe feud could have started right after Battleground as a furious Orton complains about his Punjabi Prison match before Sami interrupts him and tells him that he's received way too many opportunities at that point. Randy punches him in the face and they brawl before the rest of the roster breaks them up. The following week, Orton says that he had been holding off a lot in his chest for a while and that it's time to let it out. Orton says that he's not proud of the new generation of superstars, that most of them are incredibly overhyped by some nerds, and that Sami is on top of the list of guys he can't stand. Sami comes out and says that Orton may be right but there's only one way to prove it and that's by defeating him at Summerslam. Orton gladly accepts the challenge.\n\nThe match could be a star making opportunity for Sami Zayn. It wouldn't matter if he won or lost because his Smackdown PPV win/loss record is 2/1. As long as WWE would be willing to give Sami and Orton enough time to craft a Match of The Year contender, Sami would never leave the Barclays Center as a loser. The match could end with either Orton winning after using a heel tactic or Sami winning and then Orton brutalizing him.\n\nOrton could then go on to show more of the side that got him the only buzz he had this year when he savagely criticized independent wrestling. Perhaps he could even start a '.....Dive Open Challenge' on Smackdown where indie wrestlers would get a shot at beating Orton if they land a diving attack on him.\n\nSami would leave Summerslam as a resilient hero who gave everything he had and he would have an Apex Predator to get his revenge from which is a story that promises to be a thriller, given the quality of the babyface and heel involved.", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T23:42:00Z", "extractedDates": [{"textEnd": 28, "textStart": 14, "imp": true, "date": "2017-08-20", "amb": false}], "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "dateCrawl": "2017-08-15", "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3365109", "time": "23:42:00", "lang": "eng", "eventUri": "eng-3364258", "location": null, "concepts": [{"id": "104", "label": {"eng": "India"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India", "type": "loc", "location": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "India"}}, "score": 2}, {"id": "233", "label": {"eng": "United States"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States", "type": "loc", "location": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}, "score": 2}, {"id": "216991", "label": {"eng": "Brooklyn"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brooklyn", "type": "loc", "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Brooklyn"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}, "score": 4}, {"id": "303298", "type": "wiki", "label": {"eng": "Professional wrestling attacks"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Professional_wrestling_attacks", "score": 1}, {"id": "304688", "type": "wiki", "label": {"eng": "Glossary of professional wrestling terms"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Glossary_of_professional_wrestling_terms", "score": 4}, {"id": "307120", "type": "wiki", "label": {"eng": "Face (professional wrestling)"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Face_(professional_wrestling)", "score": 4}, {"id": "315013", "type": "person", "label": {"eng": "A.J. Barclays Center deleted a tweet that announced Lesnar would be on \"Monday Night Raw\" 24 hours after SummerSlam, according to Cageside Seats, potentially spoiling the result of the pay-per-view's main event.\n\nPaul Heyman has repeated on multiple occasions that Lesnar will leave WWE if his client loses the WWE Universal Championship at SummerSlam. Lesnar will defend his belt against Roman Reigns, Braun Strowman and Samoa Joe in a fatal 4-way match.\n\nOf course, Lesnar could lose his title and WWE could create a reason within the storyline why the former UFC Champion might show back up on TV. The more likely answer, however, is that Lesnar will remain the champion after Sunday night. He's the favorite to do so, having won the belt from Goldberg at WrestleMania 33 and successfully defended it against Joe at Great Balls of Fire.\n\nFor Cena, appearing on \"Monday Night Raw\" was the norm for many years. But the 16-time world champion has exclusively been a \"SmackDown Live\" performer since last year's brand split.\n\nJohn Cena, pictured before his match against Seth Rollins at WWE SummerSlam 2015 at Barclays Center of Brooklyn on Aug. 23, 2015 in New York City, could be on the same episode of \"Monday Night Raw\" as Brock Lesnar before the end of the summer. Photo: Getty Images\n\nCena wasn't moved during April's Superstar Shake-up, but WWE has made it clear that he will be showing up on \"Monday Night Raw\" at some point in the near future. Cena took a break from in-ring action for three months after beating The Miz at WrestleMania 33, and WWE described him as a \"free agent\" when he returned to WWE on July 4.\n\n\"The reason that I wanted to be a free agent and the reason they kind of granted my request is because I don't know if I'll be available for Smackdown specific only or Raw specific only, and I also know that my days are numbered,\" Cena told Complex last month. \"I just turned 40 in April and we have so many young and talented performers, I don't know how many years I have left. So in the time I have left, I'm gonna do what I can to dedicate to this company I just want to be able to do it the most time that I possibly can.\"\n\nCena will have a match against Baron Corbin at SummerSlam, and his free-agent status will allow him to face members of the \"Monday Night Raw\" roster at future PPV's. Don't be surprised if he challenges for the WWE Universal Championship at some point before the end of 2017.\n\nThe ability to appear on \"Monday Night Raw\" might ultimately lead to a clash between Cena and Roman Reigns at WrestleMania 34.
