Mahal's strength and pride come from his people, and what better way than to celebrate than with a special performance. We get a drummer and some Indian dancers out to perform. Mahal then asks the fans, who he calls xenophobes, to rise so that a woman can sing the Indian national anthem. The fans of course shit all over it and we get more from the dancers. He says he will beat John Cena later on, because he's the new face of the WWE because he made the company a global phenomenon. John Cena lost to Nakamura in a dream match and he will beat Cena worse than Nakamura did, and Nakamura's dream, will become a nightmare at Summerslam. Mahal then talks to his people, and Nakamura interrupts. Mahal is insulted by the interruption, but the fans love it. Nakamura says today is India's independence day, but in Japan, it's a day to commemorate those who died in war. And on Sunday in America at Summerslam will be the day Mahal loses the WWE Title... to me! This was a solid little segment to hype the Summerslam match, but Mahal's promos all run together for me. \"I love India, I love my people, you hate me because I am Indian.\" Nakamura is still rough on promos, but they are smartly keeping them short.\n\n- Commentary gives an update on Ric flair.\n\n- Naomi makes her way out to watch the match, joining commentary.\n\nNatalya vs. Becky Lynch: They work some back and forth, with Becky scoring a near fall and then they brawl, Becky looks to attack the arm, but bails to the floor, Becky hits a baseball slide dropkick as we go screen in screen on the break. Natalya tries to stall a bit, and then begs off before sending Becky to the barricade. Natalya rolls her back in and grounds Becky. Back to full screen as Becky escapes the abdominal stretch and fires up with clotheslines. The XPLODER follows, and then the running forearm connects, with Becky covering for 2. Natalya counters the arm bar, they work into some counters, and Becky hits an enziguri. Becky heads up top, but MISSES the leg drop; Natalya locks in the sharpshooter and Becky has to tap. Natalya defeated Becky Lynch @ 7:32 via submission [**] This was a solid back and forth match with the right person going over, considering Natalya is challenging for the title.\n\n- Post match Natalya locks in the sharpshooter again, but Naomi makes the save. Carmella then makes an appearance. She reminds us that she's Miss Money in the Bank, and wishes them luck at Summerslam.\n\n- Commentary hypes the Styles vs. Owens feud, including footage of Styles accidentally kicking Shane last week.\n\n- Tamina bitches at Lana because she doesn't have a match tonight. Lana says she isn't ready, and says no one notices or fears Tamina. Lana says is she follows her lead, they will. She will manipulate her way to helping her, and then Tamina will become a destructive force and they will be unstoppable.\n\n- Bryan meets with the Usos. Bryan wants to join their rap group. But they want to now which New Day members they will face at Summerslam, it will be Big E and Woods. But the Usos want Kofi & Woods tonight.\n\nRusev vs. Chad Gable: These two had a really fun outing a few weeks back. Rusev attacks at the bell, beating down Gable with ease. Gable then hits an overhead belly to belly and they spill to he floor, where Rusev shoots Gable to the steps. Rusev tosses Gable over the announce table and we get a double countout. Rusev vs. Chad Gable went to a double countout @ 1:15 [NR] personally I am a bit disappointed, because I was looking forward to these guys tearing it up again. The double countout was a bit lame, but Rusev looked like a beat prior to being laid out as Orton got revenge for last week.\n\n- Post match, Rusev applies the accolade on the table. He then grabs the mic, but before could talk, Orton hit the #RKOouttanowhere.\n\n- Lawler, Lita, Rosenberg & Otunga are all on the Summerslam preview show. Kill me now.\n\nAJ Styles Apologizes to Shane McMahon: Styles makes his way out to the ring, and calls out Shane. He does his little dance and the fans are happy to see him. Shane tells Styles if he wants to apologize, there is no reason to do so. He's there to get in between he and Owens and take a hit if need be. Styles says that the kick was an accident, but wants to know if Shane will use this to screw him over at Summerslam. Shane says it was an accident, he was in the way and it was in the heat of the battle. On Sunday, if Styles pushes or shoves him, that's a different story because he will put his hands on Styles. Styles asks if that was a threat, Shane says that what happens on Sunday... but here comes Kevin Owens before Shane could continue. Owens doesn't believe last week was an accident. He wants to make something clear, and says if he makes contact with Shane on Sunday, it would be an accident. He knows Shane will call things down the middle and will be winning his title back. Owens offers to shake Styles' hand, things get chippy and Shane tries to break then up. Styles almost hits Shane but Shane blocks it and yells at him. This leads to Owens trying to superkick Styles, but he moves and Owens lays out Shane. I liked this and thought it was good. I dig the mind games they are playing heading into the match. I still think that the end game is Styles retaining, leading to Owens vs. Shane at HIAC.\n\n- New Day cut a pre-match promo, hyping tonight's match and the match at Summerslam.\n\nNon-Title Match: The Usos vs. Champions New Day (Xavier Woods & Kofi Kingston): Kofi controls at the bell, laying in kicks and then working quick tags with Woods as they keep a fast pace and work rapid fire double teams. The battle goes to the floor as we go screen in screen for the break. Back in the ring, the Usos take control of things working over Kofi. They ground him and keep him on tier side of the ring, while working quick tags. Back to full screen, Kofi works to his feet but quickly gets beat down. The heat is solid here; Kofi eventually hits a belly to back suplex and tags in Woods. He runs wild and hits the honor roll. The enziguri follows, Kofi blind tags in and New Day hits double superkicks for the near fall. The midnight hour is cut off, and the Usos attack Kofi's knee and hit double superkicks and pick up the win. The Usos defeated Champions New Day @ 7:23 via pin [**\u00be] This was pretty good, and while the New Day lineup will be different on Sunday, I am not a fan of WWE giving away another Summerslam match on TV. It feels lazy, like they had no idea how to fill their TV time this week.\n\n- Time for The Fashion Peaks finale. Fandango talks about the aliens probed him deep, mentally. Breeze is dressed in drag again, and says they need to solve some mysteries so that people don't think tat they are making this up as they go along. Fandango has a space rock and throws it. The Ascension arrives, returning the pie from last week. Fandango finds hair in it, and a Band-Aid. He then finds gluten and Viktor flips out because he lives a gluten free life. They then find a note that says \"Two B.\" Fandango licks the note as they fear for the entire tag division. They will return in two weeks. The mystery remains unsolved.\n\nNon-Title Match: WWE Champion Jinder Mahal vs. John Cena: We get the dueling Cena chants and they work a test of strength to begin. They work power for power, and the Singhs get involved allowing Mahal to take control. Cena sent to the floor as we go to commercial. Post break and Mahal controls as Phillips tries to sell this as the biggest main event in Smackdown history. Cena starts to make a comeback; plays the hits and the Singhs pull Mahal to the floor to save him. Cena chases, but the Singhs get involved again and then tossed to the back. Cena locks in the STF, but Mahal makes the ropes. Mahal fights off the AA and stuns Cena off the ropes. He follows with the knee strike for 2. Mahal sets for the khallas, but Cena powers out and hits the AA but Mahal kicks out. Cena seems shocked, but everyone kicks out of the AA it seems. Cena takes Mahal to the ropes, hits the second rope AA and Corbin is out for the DQ. {"id": "9963829", "categories": [{"id": 111, "label": "dmoz/Arts/Television", "uri": "dmoz/Arts/Television", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 212, "label": "dmoz/Arts/Television/Programs", "uri": "dmoz/Arts/Television/Programs", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 596, "label": "dmoz/Arts/Radio/Formats", "uri": "dmoz/Arts/Radio/Formats", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 1184, "label": "dmoz/Sports/Wrestling/Professional", "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Wrestling/Professional", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-18", "uri": "711623959", "source": {"id": "335", "title": "USA Today", "uri": "usatoday.com"}, "url": "https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/2017/08/18/summerslam-wwe-preview-tv-information-rundown/579974001/", "body": "CONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE\n\nWWE is bringing SummerSlam back to Brooklyn, N.Y., for its second biggest show of the year.\n\nWHEN: The four-hour pay-per-view begins at 7 p.m. ET on Sunday, Aug. 20, with the kickoff show set to begin at 5.\n\nHOW TO WATCH: SummerSlam can be seen on WWE Network.\n\nWHERE: Barclays Center, Brooklyn, N.Y. WWE also has announced that SummerSlam weekend will return to Brooklyn for a fourth consecutive year in 2018.\n\nMORE: NXT TakeOver: Brooklyn III airs Saturday at 8 p.m. ET on WWE Network with Bobby Roode defending the NXT title against Drew McIntyre in the main event. After SummerSlam, the WWE Network will feature a bracketology special for the Mae Young Classic, the upcoming women's tournament that features 32 competitors from around the world. The first four hourlong episodes of the tournament will be available on WWE Network beginning Aug. 28.\n\nMORE WWE:\n\nJohn Cena has perfect response to fan who made obscene gesture to him\n\nSamoa Joe's long journey to WWE shows he's always ready to fight\n\nWWE's Alexa Bliss embraces being 'Five Feet of Fury'\n\nTHE RUNDOWN\n\nKICKOFF SHOW\n\nWWE Cruiserweight championship, Akira Tozawa defends against Neville. In a surprise, Tozawa won the title from Neville on Monday's RAW before the two were scheduled to meet at SummerSlam. Neville, who won the title in January, has been the one true star as WWE has tried to to get the cruiserweight division to gain traction with the fans.\n\nSmackdown Tag Team championship, The New Day defends against The Usos. Odd that this match ends up on the Kickoff Show, but that also might allow for more time with Kickoff Show extended to two hours. It also is unique that WWE revealed in advance which two members of The New Day would be competing.\n\nSix-man tag team match, Matt and Jeff Hardy and Jason Jordan against The Miz, Bo Dallas and Curtis Axel. A shoulder injury to Scott Dawson of The Revival left the Hardys without a SummerSlam opponent. A singles match between Jordan and The Miz on RAW marred by interference from Dallas and Axel led to a six-man match when the Hardys hit the ring. This is a rematch of that bout. This could be Jordan's opportunity to shine and potentially mean an Intercontinental title match against The Miz.\n\nMAIN SHOW\n\nBig Show vs. Big Cass. It's a battle of the \"Bigs,\" but Cass is on the ascent after breaking up with longtime partner Enzo Amore. Cass, with help from Luke Gallows and Karl Anderson, \"broke\" Big Show's hand on RAW and that injury provides an opening for WWE to continue to highlight Cass' vicious side. A win also will give Cass the bragging rights among big men. Amore will be suspended above the ring in a shark cage. The shark cage was a rarely used stipulation that has become in vogue with WWE as this will be its third use this year.\n\nRandy Orton vs. Rusev. The reasoning behind this match is a bit of a stretch. But with John Cena expected to move to RAW, 13-time former champion Orton will be needed to fill a bigger role on Smackdown. He is coming off a number of pay-per-view losses, so this is his chance to turn the tide.\n\nSmackdown Women's Championship, Naomi defends against Natalya. This seemed like an obvious spot for a Naomi victory and then Carmella cashing in the Money In The Bank briefcase. But with Baron Corbin cashing in his briefcase on Smackdown this week, it's hard to see WWE wanting neither briefcase in play so quickly. Natalya hasn't held a title since 2010 and her stalwart work in the ring and behind the scenes deserves to be rewarded. Rematches between Natalya and either Charlotte Flair or Becky Lynch would be great.\n\nBaron Corbin vs. John Cena. Cena is expected to head to RAW so WWE could build back up Corbin win a victory. If WWE still believes in Corbin - and that is in question after the usage of the Money in the Bank contract was squandered - he needs to win here. If it doesn't, Cena is still Cena and he gets the victory. Word is Cena's fiancee, Nikki Bella, who has not been on WWE programming since WrestleMania, could be at ringside with sister Brie.\n\nFinn Balor vs. Bray Wyatt. So much for a surprise return for \"The Demon.\" After getting doused with red goop Monday night on RAW, Balor will unleash his own demon character for the first time since his return from injury. Balor has largely been in limbo since coming back. Wyatt has had the advantage in this feud thus far. The return of the demon doesn't mean an obvious victory for Balor, but ...\n\nRAW Tag Team championship, Sheamus and Cesaro defend against Seth Rollins and Dean Ambrose. Based on the crowd reaction, the fans really, really wanted a Shield reunion. And now they have it. As good as Sheamus and Cesaro have been, the time is right for Rollins and Ambrose, especially since the Hardys are the only other fan favorite tag team on the RAW roster.\n\nRAW Women's championship, Alexa Bliss defends against Sasha Banks. This gets interesting when you consider that the match was supposed to be Bliss against Bayley. A shoulder injury sidelined Bayley and Banks won a No. 1 contender's match against Nia Jax. That could open the door for Banks to get a more prominent title run. She is a three-time champion, but she and Charlotte flipped the belt several times in a short period of time. But there is argument to made that Bliss has been as good as anyone on either roster of late and more time with the title would only serve her well.\n\nUnited States championship, A.J. Styles defends against Kevin Owens. Styles and Owens have a history of show-stealing matches; the new dynamic here is that Shane McMahon serves as special referee. Well, Styles and McMahon worked each other at WrestleMania. Does this set the stage for Owens and McMahon at some point? After switching the title a few times, Styles should get a longer run. Owens has proved he can do virtually anything; he doesn't need a championship.\n\nWWE championship, Jinder Mahal defends against Shinsuke Nakamura. Many expected Cena in this spot - even Mahal had expressed an interest in facing the 16-time champion at SummerSlam. Here is where the \"business\" of the wrestling business applies: WWE is heading for a tour of India soon; having Mahal go into the tour as the champion makes sense. Nakamura is hugely popular and returns to Brooklyn, where he won the NXT title during SummerSlam weekend last year. Or could WWE get two bites of the apple by having Nakaura win in Brooklyn and then lose the title to Mahal in India?\n\nUniversal championship, Fatal Four-Way, Brock Lesnar defends against Braun Strowman, Roman Reigns and Samoa Joe. The good news is WWE will be just fine with any of them winning and a compelling argument can be made for each. A stipulation has been added that Lesnar and advocate Paul Heyman say they will leave WWE if Lesnar loses, citing the match is unfair to the champion. Lesnar does not have to lose to lose the belt. That stipulation plays into the furor of a possible Lesnar return to UFC to face Jon Jones. Lesnar isn't going anywhere until WrestleMania in April, but could he lose and move to Smackdown? We have seen Lesnar have one-on-one matches with Joe and with Reigns. We have yet to see one against Strowman - who keeps getting better and better. Lesnar could retain here and then meet Strowman next month at the No Mercy pay-per-view.\n\nCONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE", "dateTime": "2017-08-18T19:32:00Z", "extractedDates": [{"textEnd": 202, "textStart": 195, "imp": true, "date": "2017-08-20", "amb": false}, {"textEnd": 889, "textStart": 882, "imp": true, "date": "2017-08-28", "amb": false}], "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "dateCrawl": "2017-08-18", "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3365109", "time": "19:32:00", "lang": "eng", "eventUri": "eng-3364258", "location": null, "concepts": [{"id": "104", "label": {"eng": "India"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India", "type": "loc", "location": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "India"}}, "score": 1}, {"id": "233", "label": {"eng": "United States"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States", "type": "loc", "location": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}, "score": 2}, {"id": "216991", "label": {"eng": "Brooklyn"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brooklyn", "type": "loc", "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Brooklyn"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}, "score": 5}, {"id": "307120", "type": "wiki", "label": {"eng": "Face (professional wrestling)"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Face_(professional_wrestling)", "score": 2}, {"id": "313955", "type": "wiki", "label": {"eng": "Shark"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shark", "score": 4}, {"id": "315013", "type": "person", "label": {"eng": "A.J. {"id": "10021845", "categories": [{"id": 41, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 804, "label": "dmoz/Society/People/Celebrities", "uri": "dmoz/Society/People/Celebrities", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 1055, "label": "dmoz/Sports/Wrestling", "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Wrestling", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 1056, "label": "dmoz/Sports/Wrestling/Amateur", "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Wrestling/Amateur", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 1184, "label": "dmoz/Sports/Wrestling/Professional", "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Wrestling/Professional", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-18", "uri": "711799882", "source": {"id": "1722", "title": "Sporting News", "uri": "sportingnews.com"}, "url": "http://www.sportingnews.com/ca/wwe/news/summerslam-2017-jinder-mahal-wwe-championship-transformation-india/1r950yhh4bnvg12tvh8tnfjyvi", "body": "NEW YORK -- Jinder Mahal's submission move is the Camel Clutch, but make no mistake, the 31-year-old Mahal is a Sharpshooter guy.\n\nWhat else would one expect from a Calgary boy?\n\nMahal's most recent push in WWE has led to him holding the WWE Championship on \"SmackDown Live.\" His next title defense will come this Sunday at Barclays Center where Mahal will take on Shinsuke Nakamura. He just finished up a program with Randy Orton that spanned three pay-per-views, with Mahal going over in each match.\n\nBut a few weeks ago, Mahal brought his belt with him to attend his brother's wedding in their hometown, north of the border, where Mahal's love for wrestling cultivated during his formative years.\n\nMORE: Getting a grip -- Ric Flair update, \"SummerSlam\" predictions\n\n\"Just growing up with Indian parents, my parents were at work a lot of the time, so I grew up just watching wrestling,\" Mahal said. \"This is how I learned about life. Through Bret Hart I learned anything is possible.\"\n\nMahal idolized Hart, following and trying to emulate his every move. Hart was the last Calgarian to hold a WWE Championship before Mahal won his off Orton at the \"Backlash\" pay-per-view in May.\n\n\"I might have put my brother in the Sharpshooter (when we were kids),\" Mahal said with a laugh.\n\nSo when Mahal returned home to celebrate his brother's wedding with his family, the belt came with him, making its triumphant return to Calgary.\n\n\"After 20 years it was very cool that the championship was back in the city,\" Mahal said. \"Their response was great. Everywhere I went in Calgary the city was very, very happy. The WWE universe now understands it's character-driven, it's entertainment, but it's still not everyday that there's a champion from the city. So everybody is proud of me.\"\n\nMahal's wrestling journey, one which saw him cut from WWE in 2014, dictates how he talks about his future. His rise in the company coincides with a self-described regained focus. He completely changed his eating and workout habits, adding 16 pounds of muscle. The wrestler fans see now is -- in some respects -- a caricature of the in-ring product they grew accustomed to.\n\nMORE: Three times wrestling fans didn't get who they wanted\n\n\"When I got released obviously it was a huge blow, I was disappointed, I was sad, all those things because I wanted to be a WWE superstar my whole life and to have that taken away from me did really suck,\" Mahal said. \"But at the same time I was kind of happy almost, too. Where I was at mentally, I wasn't really in the game 100 percent. I wasn't happy with my position, which was my fault.\"\n\nBig thanks to the @nutritionsolutions family and @chriscavallini for surprising me at the head office today. Changing my diet was one of the first steps I took, a very big step in my transformation which led me to become #WWEChampion. On one cake is a pic me before I regained my focus, and the other cake is a pic of me after my match at Backlash... ps. this doesn't mean I had any cake ..\n\nA post shared by The Maharaja (@jindermahal) on May 24, 2017 at 11:50am PDT\n\nBut even when WWE brought him back, Mahal said, where he's currently at physically and mentally is leaps-and-bounds a better position than when he was re-signed.\n\nChanging his life changed the company's attitude toward him as a performer, and then came his big push.\n\nAround \"WrestleMania 33,\" Mahal said he started hearing from a bunch of writers, including former WWE superstar and current backstage producer Road Dogg who told him \"big things coming after WrestleMania.\"\n\nThen he was moved to \"SmackDown,\" where Mahal said -- in his best-case scenario -- he believed he would be competing for either the United States or Intercontinental Championship, mid-card titles.\n\nMORE: Five main-event acts rejected by WWE fans\n\nThen finally came the night that Mahal finally realized the scope of the company's plans for him. He was backstage in the trainer's room during a taping of \"RAW.\" The WWE account tweeted that he would be a participant in a six-man match the following night to determine the No. 1 contender to face WWE Champion Orton. Mahal began to wonder who would win, thinking maybe it would be Luke Harper or Sami Zayn.\n\n\"At that time I was receiving tweets, people were like, 'Why is Jinder even considered in the No. 1 (contender) match?',\" Mahal said. \"And then one of the boys told me, 'You're going in with Randy next,' and I was like, 'What?' and then I saw Randy, he came into the trainer's room, and he was like, 'I think we're working soon.'\"\n\nFrom growing up dreaming of being a professional wrestler, idolizing Hart, making the company, but then getting cut, Mahal saw the fruits of his newest labor.\n\n\"WWE is very unpredictable,\" Mahal said. \"I knew even though I could be winning, I didn't want to get too excited. It was a weird feeling when I became WWE champion. I didn't have a huge moment of celebration because my goals were a lot bigger than this. I knew now I needed to step up.\"\n\nMahal is quick to note he doesn't want to be a flash in the pan. His long-term, personal itinerary includes being a multiple-time WWE Champion, and eventually a member of the WWE Hall of Fame.\n\nMORE: \"WrestleMania\" matches that failed to deliver -- or didn't happen\n\n\"I had to prove myself in and outside of the ring because not only am I responsible for what happens inside the ring, but outside of the ring I represent WWE as a company,\" Mahal said. \"I'm the face of WWE. I'm very, very responsible. I take this very, very seriously. I'm not going to do anything to jeopardize the integrity of this championship, or the integrity of WWE.\"\n\nIn Mahal, WWE has a global face. He's billed as a champion who represents India. They've tacked on \"The Modern Day Maharaja\" as his nickname. He held a Punjabi celebration on \"SmackDown\" following his WWE Championship victory, and celebrated India's Independence Day this past Tuesday.\n\nIt's also a sensitive subject that Mahal is aware of. Positioned as a heel, fans boo him incessantly. In the promos he gives, he responds by saying they dislike him because he's different, which, in America's current cultural and socio-climate, is a topic that almost veers too from into kayfabe.\n\n\"WWE is very aware, and if anything were to ever arise I could speak up and say, 'I'm not comfortable doing this,' and for sure (WWE CEO Vince McMahon) wouldn't want to do it,\" Mahal said. \"WWE is very aware of sensitivity, and WWE is a global company. They don't want to offend anyone in any country.\"\n\nHe also said the WWE has long had a big presence in India, and though he's been with the company for years, his push only came after he started to really dedicate himself to the product.\n\n\"A lot of people say, 'Oh, you became champion because of India' but I was still the same person when I was when I got signed, when I debuted in 2011,\" Mahal said. \"(The Great) Khali raised it up to such a very high level, and they didn't make me WWE Champion or World Heavyweight Champion at that point. It wasn't until I was ready.\n\nMahal said he likes being booed. The heel is a dying breed in professional wrestling, Mahal said, but the reaction is one he has embraced.\n\n\"It's more fun being a bad guy,\" Mahal said. \"It's a cool dynamic now because the curtain has been pulled back a little bit. People know what we do is entertainment. So people like me, but instead of cheering me, they'll boo me out of respect. It's very cool nowadays.\"", "dateTime": "2017-08-18T21:16:00Z", "extractedDates": [{"textEnd": 3058, "textStart": 3046, "date": "2017-05-24", "amb": false}], "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "dateCrawl": Once again, the pay-per-view will be held at the Barclays Center in Brooklyn as will Raw on the following night, and those running the arena's social media may have gotten ahead of themselves. In the last week, a few tweets may have spoiled the PPV main event and a huge surprise for Monday.\n\nEarly on Wednesday, the official Twitter account of the Barclays Center took to promoting their huge WWE events coming up on Sunday and Monday. As reported by PW Mania, one of their tweets was for Monday Night Raw on August 21, and it revealed that Brock Lesnar will be there in person.\n\nUnfortunately for those that saw it, there was another bit of information in the tweet that was quickly deleted, but many still caught what it said.\n\n\"JUST ANNOUNCED: Universal Champion \"The Beast\" @BrockLesnar will be live on @WWE #RAW this Monday, 8/21! pic.twitter.com/FUAr7G2Bi7\n\n-- Barclays Center (@barclayscenter) August 16, 2017''\n\nAs you can see, it is saying that Brock Lesnar will be the Universal Champion on Monday night which means he would be the one winning in the main event of SummerSlam.\n\nMany said that they just said this because he is the current WWE Universal Champion, but it doesn't mean that SummerSlam was spoiled. Others pointed out the storyline where Paul Heyman said his client would leave WWE if he lost the Universal Title this Sunday at the PPV.\n\nIf Brock Lesnar is scheduled to be on Monday Night Raw, that seems to mean he will still be the champion by that time.\n\nThis tweet was deleted, but the Barclays Center Twitter account posted another spoiler-filled announcement last week. Everyone knows that John Cena is currently listed as a \"free agent\" and set to face Baron Corbin at SummerSlam, but Pop Culture caught a tweet that may have spoiled his return date to Raw.\n\nWith his free agent status, he can jump brands as he sees fit, but it appears he's headed for Monday nights very soon. It's just interesting that the Barclays Center left this tweet up but deleted the one about Lesnar.\n\nNo matter what ends up happening, WWE has the ability to change things up at the last minute and alter these spoilers if they're actually true. SummerSlam still has to take place on Sunday night before Monday Night Raw can begin, and that's a lot of decision making that needs to be done. For the third consecutive year, it will be at the Barclays Center in Brooklyn and feature a full slate of matches from Raw and SmackDown Live.\n\nThe main event of SummerSlam will see Brock Lesnar defend the WWE Universal Championship against Roman Reigns, Braun Strowman, and Samoa Joe. If Lesnar loses, he will leave the WWE.\n\nJinder Mahal will defend the WWE Championship against Shinsuke Nakamura. This is after Nakamura won a No. 1 Contenders match against John Cena on SmackDown Live.\n\nOutside of these two matches, there will be 10 others at SummerSlam. How could they all finish? Who will walk out with titles? Let's predict the entire show.\n\nRandy Orton and Rusev haven't had the best summers on SmackDown Live. They were in different positions on the match card but struggled to look competitive.\n\nOrton rivaled Jinder Mahal for three months as they battled for the WWE Championship. Mahal won the title at May's Backlash, which led to two more pay-per-view matches. The Viper lost both and seemed to be aimless.\n\nRusev was supposed to come back for Money in the Bank. Remember his demand for a title match at the June PPV? That never happened, and he didn't return until the first week of July, at the same time as John Cena. One messy Flag Match later and the Bulgarian Brute looked lost.\n\nSo when WWE has two superstars doing nothing, what do they do? They throw them into a match at SummerSlam with little-to-no build and hope they put on a good match. It's potentially a one-off before Orton and Rusev go in different directions, or the start of a program for the fall.\n\nGiven the Apex Predator's losses throughout the summer, look for him to rebound with a big win. This doesn't help Rusev, who will go grounded into SmackDown Live. Nakamura is in a WWE Championship bout against Jinder Mahal. Joe is one of four hosses set to battle in a Fatal 4-Way match for the Universal Championship.\n\nYoung stars will make their SummerSlam debuts. Well-traveled grapplers just beginning to make their mark on WWE will grace the PPV's stage too.\n\nShort builds are poised to hamper a handful of the bouts, but there should be plenty of thrillers and memorable moments at the summer blockbuster. Count on AJ Styles and Kevin Owens to deliver in their U.S. title bout. And don't sleep on Alexa Bliss vs. Sasha Banks for the Raw Women's Championship.\n\nOn Sunday, Barclays Center in Brooklyn, New York, is set to welcome stars old and new, talent representing the past and the future, in one of WWE biggest events of the year.\n\nPaul Heyman has promised that if Lesnar loses on Sunday, both he and his client will leave WWE. That subplot added a great wrinkle and deepened the suspense around the bout. That was until Barclays Center's social media team jumped the gun.\n\nAs Total Wrestling magazine pointed out, the arena's Twitter account announced Lesnar would be at Raw the next night:\n\nThat points to Lesnar retaining the Universal Championship. Barclays Center staff aren't the only ones providing potential spoilers on the bout. As Dave Meltzer noted on Figure Four Online: \"Lesnar is advertised for more dates after the pay-per-view as well.\"\n\nNikki Bella mentioned that she would be in the front row for fiance Cena's match against Baron Corbin:\n\nHer sister may make an appearance as well. Brie Bella is set to be in SummerSlam's host city. Mike Johnson of PWInsider.com said \"Brie Bella will be in New York City this weekend,\" noting that she would be in town to film Total Divas.\n\nAnd as for whether Carmella will cash in her Money in the Bank contract on Naomi or Natalya come Sunday, she hinted at waiting to pounce. In an interview with Gorilla Position (via Ash Rose of TalkSport), The Princess of Staten Island said: \"At the moment, my plan is to hold onto the contract as long as I can.\"\n\nThe numbers are likely to shift again just before the PPV, but the betting odds suggest we'll see three new champions crowned at Barclays Center. The numbers also point to Cena breaking his six-match losing streak at SummerSlam on Sunday.\n\nThe SummerSlams odds, as of Friday, are as follows, per OddsShark:\n\nCass is the biggest favorite of the night with minus-600 odds (bet $600 to win $100). That's an implied probability of 85.7 percent. It looks like Amore is going to have watch his former friend score his biggest career win to date.\n\nThe slow, hesitant reunion of Dean Ambrose and Seth Rollins has been one of Raw's best stories during SummerSlam season. The two former members of The Shield still don't trust each other, but they have decided to unite against a common enemy.\n\nNamely Raw tag champs Cesaro and Sheamus.\n\nCesaro and Sheamus began as hated enemies who were forced together as a duo. They are now a cohesive, overwhelming machine.\n\nAmbrose and Rollins' reunion will be fun to watch. The action is sure to be hard-hitting. And the threat of the challengers imploding mid-match will add plenty of suspense.\n\nAJ Styles and Kevin Owens have traded the U.S. title over the past few weeks.\n\nKO was robbed of his latest attempt to win the gold back when a referee mistakenly counted to three while Owens' shoulders were up. SmackDown Live Commissioner Shane McMahon has stepped in to make sure there are no mistakes this next time around.\n\nMcMahon has quickly become as vital to this narrative as Styles and Owens. His past as a shady referee, his violent history with Styles and the tension between him and KO add depth to a match made fresh by his addition.\n\nStyles and Owens haven't yet had the truly great match fans have been expecting from them. If Shane-O-Mac's presence deepens the bout rather than gets in its way, that is set to change on Sunday.\n\nAlexa Bliss thought she was going to face Bayley at SummerSlam, but a shoulder injury forced WWE to shift gears. Banks won a Triple Threat match and then defeated Nia Jax to earn the right to be Bayley's replacement.\n\nAnd The Boss is ready to get her hands on the woman who evaded her at Great Balls of Fire in July.\n\nThe rivals' well-documented real-life tension is sure to add to the in-ring excitement. Their strong chemistry assures that this will be one of the night's better offerings.\n\nWWE could mix things up too, by inserting Bliss' sometimes bodyguard, Jax, or having Banks' friend Bayley play into this as an invested spectator.\n\nSmackDown's penchant for throwing curveballs continued through the road to SummerSlam when Nakamura pushed past Cena to claim the No. 1 contender's spot for the WWE crown.\n\nThat created a meeting between two men making their SummerSlam debuts in a high-profile bout for the company's oldest title.\n\nMahal shocked the world by even being in this spot. He went from midcarder to marquee star in a rapid rise during the spring. After dispatching Orton several times, he is set to face a man with an unpredictable style and a mule-like kick.\n\nTheir clash of styles alone will be worth watching as the slower-paced Mahal collides with the electric showboat that is The King of Strong Style.\n\nGet ready to rearrange your Match of the Year lists. The Fatal 4-Way match for Lesnar's universal title is going to be a slobberknocker for the ages.\n\nStrowman blasted Reigns at Great Balls of Fire to put himself into the contender conversation. Reigns believed he deserved a shot thanks to his lengthy resume and the beating he put on The Monster Among Men after losing to him. Joe nearly toppled Lesnar at that same July PPV.\n\nChaos unfolded, with Raw general manager Kurt Angle trying to figure out which Superstar should face The Beast Incarnate. So he opted to put all three of them into the battle.\n\nHe made the right choice. The resulting savagery that will be SummerSlam's main event will be out of this world.\n\nAnd if the Raw side of the creative team is as bold as SmackDown's, it will script a win for either Strowman or Joe and let a new monster reign over the red brand coming out of SummerSlam.", "dateTime": "2017-08-19T10:11:00Z", "extractedDates": null, "sim": 0.686274528503418, "dateCrawl": "2017-08-19", "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3373948", "time": "10:11:00", "lang": "eng", "eventUri": "eng-3364258", "location": null, "concepts": [{"id": "233", "label": {"eng": "United States"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States", "type": "loc", "location": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}, "score": 4}, {"id": "216991", "label": {"eng": "Brooklyn"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brooklyn", "type": "loc", "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Brooklyn"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}, "score": 3}, {"id": "218049", "label": {"eng": "New York City"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_City", "type": "loc", "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "New York City"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}, "score": 3}, {"id": "302546", "type": "org", "label": {"eng": "Twitter"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twitter", "score": 3}, {"id": "303298", "type": "wiki", "label": {"eng": "Professional wrestling attacks"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Professional_wrestling_attacks", "score": 1}, {"id": "307120", "type": "wiki", "label": {"eng": "Face (professional wrestling)"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Face_(professional_wrestling)", "score": 4}, {"id": "315013", "type": "person", "label": {"eng": "A.J. {"id": "9979606", "categories": [{"id": 7, "label": "dmoz/Arts", "uri": "dmoz/Arts", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 114, "label": "dmoz/Arts/Performing Arts/Theatre", "uri": "dmoz/Arts/Performing_Arts/Theatre", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 211, "label": "dmoz/Society/People/Men", "uri": "dmoz/Society/People/Men", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 550, "label": "dmoz/Society/Future", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Future", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 561, "label": "dmoz/Games/Video Games/Sports", "uri": "dmoz/Games/Video_Games/Sports", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 1055, "label": "dmoz/Sports/Wrestling", "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Wrestling", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 1056, "label": "dmoz/Sports/Wrestling/Amateur", "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Wrestling/Amateur", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 1184, "label": "dmoz/Sports/Wrestling/Professional", "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Wrestling/Professional", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-18", "uri": "711668780", "source": {"id": "3199", "title": "Bleacher Report", "uri": "bleacherreport.com"}, "url": "http://bleacherreport.com/articles/2726778-jinder-mahal-on-meteoric-rise-in-wwe-randy-orton-feud-and-shinsuke-nakamura", "body": "At SummerSlam 2017, Jinder Mahal will stride into New York's Barclays Center as WWE champion, a chiseled titan glistening in the spotlight.\n\nHe will have gone from being handed a pink slip to carrying championship gold in less than a year. The WWE title match against Shinsuke Nakamura at Sunday's pay-per-view will be the biggest bout of his career. This will all come after the comic relief-turned-headliner experienced one of the most surprising turnarounds ever.\n\nBut this isn't the climax of Mahal's journey in his mind. This is simply the beginning.\n\nThe Maharaja remains humble despite the gold he carries over his shoulder and being positioned as SmackDown's top heel. He's hungry, focused and still in awe of where he is today.\n\n\"I've never performed at a SummerSlam event before,\" Mahal told Bleacher Report. \"And to come in as WWE champion against someone like Shinsuke Nakamura who is already a legend in the business, it's a very, very special moment.\"\n\nHis uncle Gama Singh, a wrestling star in Canada in the '70s and '80s, helped instill that attitude.\n\nMahal was a young boy when Singh prowled the rings in Calgary, Toronto, and beyond. But when Mahal decided to enter the squared circle himself, his uncle helped guide him. Bad News Brown, Gerry Morrow and Singh all had a hand in training a young Mahal.\n\n\"As I was getting into this business, he was a huge help, someone to go to for advice,\" Mahal explained.\n\nAfter winning the WWE title from Randy Orton at Backlash in May, the new champ's celebration didn't end in the ring. He showed off his newly won prize with a man he views as a mentor and father figure.\n\n\"I was able to take the WWE Championship over to his house, and he was very proud. We took some pictures. It was a very proud moment, a cool moment,\" Mahal recalled.\n\nNow that Mahal is on top of the WWE world, his uncle has offered words of wisdom that echo in his head: \"Remain humble. Don't let all this get to your head. This doesn't last forever.\"\n\nIn his hometown of Calgary, Mahal first put his uncle's teaching to the test as a member of Stampede Wrestling.\n\nThe promotion was also home to Tyson Kidd, David Hart Smith, Natalya and Viktor of The Ascension, who would all later make their way to WWE. Mahal referred to them as a close-knit group. He said many of his peers at Stampede Wrestling were \"already great wrestlers\" when he arrived on the scene and remembers those beginnings fondly.\n\n\"The crowds weren't always the biggest, but we just had all this passion. We were lucky enough to get to perform every week in Calgary,\" he said.\n\nThe size of the audiences ballooned big time when Mahal made his SmackDown debut in 2011.\n\nBut his ride to the top sputtered out before it really got started. WWE reassigned him to its developmental territory in 2012, and he later re-emerged alongside Drew McIntyre and Heath Slater as 3MB, a trio of wannabe rockers with a penchant for playing air guitars.\n\nThe comedy group lasted until the summer of 2014, when WWE released both McIntyre and Mahal.\n\nThree years later, Mahal is poised to defend the WWE title at SummerSlam. McIntyre will challenge Bobby Roode for the NXT Championship at TakeOver: Brooklyn III the night before.\n\nReflecting on how far his friend and former stablemate has come, Mahal said, \"To see where he is now is just a testament to the hard work he's put in.\"\n\nMahal is confident McIntyre is in line for big things.\n\n\"I definitely know he's going to be WWE champion some day,\" Mahal promised. In fact, he said that before McIntyre was set to wrestle one night, Mahal texted him: \"Be careful, we have a WrestleMania to main event someday.\"\n\nWWE cutting both men fueled them.\n\n\"Both of us have a chip on our shoulder because we were released. I know that I do,\" Mahal said. \"I hope I never lose that chip. It motivates me. It keeps me working hard each day.\"\n\nThat drive has him seeing beyond the title matches this weekend, beyond where he stands today. The Maharaja believes the future is bright for both him and McIntyre.\n\n\"This is just the beginning for both of us. We have a long career ahead of us. He's 32, I'm 31,\" Mahal said. \"We haven't even hit our prime yet. And I'm excited to see what the future brings.\"\n\nThe immediate future is a date with Nakamura, the eccentric Japanese star known for swift kicks and kneeing people in the head.\n\nAfter a series of clashes with Orton, Mahal will have to make a major adjustment. Orton and Nakamura's styles couldn't be more different. The Viper has a more traditional approach, with a slower pace and homages to the likes of Ronnie Garvin and his father Cowboy Bob Orton. Nakamura instead seems to be channeling Freddie Mercury of Queen in the ring.\n\nMahal was impressed with what he saw out of Orton from close range.\n\n\"He's a natural. I've never been in the ring with someone like that. Randy just makes it looks so, so easy,\" Mahal said.\n\nAs for The King of Strong Style, Mahal isn't as sure what to expect.\n\n\"He's hard to study. He's hard to predict,\" Mahal explained. \"He's a lot more unpredictable. He's surgical with those strikes. He's a different kind of intense.\"\n\nAnd even though Nakamura has been IWGP heavyweight champion for New Japan Pro Wrestling and wrestled in the Tokyo Dome, Mahal called this SummerSlam clash Nakamura's biggest match yet.\n\n\"This is WWE. This is the WWE Universe. This is SummerSlam. This is Barclays,\" he said.\n\nWith that constant chip on his shoulder, The Singh Brothers in his corner and the WWE title on the line, Mahal is ready to make the most of that stage. In part, he wants to represent the SmackDown brand, to outdo Raw, which is nothing new.\n\n\"The whole SmackDown roster has a chip on its shoulder. People think of us as a secondary show, but each and every night, we work our tail off and put on the better show,\" Mahal said.\n\nAnd when he and Nakamura collide, The Maharaja expects to make a lasting statement. This bout isn't just about the here and now, it's about these two men putting their stamp on the brand for years to come.\n\n\"We're going to establish ourselves as long-term players. This year, all but one championship will be on the line on a night that could be Brock Lesnar's last in WWE.\n\nHere is your guide to what to look for and expect when the company's second biggest pay-per-view invades Brooklyn, starting with a two-hour pre-show at 5 p.m. on the WWE Network.\n\nThe Universal champion's advocate Paul Heyman has said they both will leave WWE if Lesnar is not victorious in a fatal-four-way match for his title against Samoa Joe, Braun Strowman, and Roman Regins. UFC light heavyweight champion Jon Jones has already called out Lesnar, so there is a real-life reason to hype up the storyline and believe this situation is real.\n\nIt likely is not. Lesnar's deal with WWE reportedly ends with next year's WrestleMania and he would still need to finish out the second half of his USADA suspension from UFC 200 last July. The Beast and the title are probably staying put.\n\nNakamura, an international superstar, earned his match with WWE champion Jinder Mahal by beating John Cena clean in a No. 1 contender's match. The match has gotten very little build and Nakamura's push has been gradual since debuting on the main roster. This goes one of two ways: Nakamura wins clean and a long title reign begins or Mahal's buddies the Singh Brothers interfere and Nakamura gets cheated out of a victory or wins by DQ to set up a rematch with higher stakes.\n\nWWE squandered one of its biggest cheat pop elements Tuesday night on SmackDown Live when Baron Corbin waited too long to cash in his Money in the Bank briefcase for Mahal's WWE title. Instead of a huge story-turning moment, Corbin was rolled up by Mahal and lost - much to the joy of his SummerSlam opponent John Cena.\n\nThe flawed decision not only downgraded Corbin's character, it took the briefcase off the table Sunday and likely means we won't see Carmella cash her's in on the winner of Naomi and Natalya's SmackDown women's title match. Expect Carmella to at least try to cash in because the moment has been teased too much for her not to.\n\nFormer Shield members Dean Ambrose and Seth Rollins finally got on the same page last week, both putting their fists out in solidary. They now get a chance to win the Raw tag team title from Sheamus and Cesaro.\n\nBig Cass and Enzo Amore couldn't be further apart after Cass turned heel and Amore's new friend Big Show will try to teach him a lesson. {"id": "10048218", "categories": [{"id": 7, "label": "dmoz/Arts", "uri": "dmoz/Arts", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 106, "label": "dmoz/Business/Industrial Goods and Services/Industrial Supply", "uri": "dmoz/Business/Industrial_Goods_and_Services/Industrial_Supply", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 111, "label": "dmoz/Arts/Television", "uri": "dmoz/Arts/Television", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 212, "label": "dmoz/Arts/Television/Programs", "uri": "dmoz/Arts/Television/Programs", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 244, "label": "dmoz/Shopping/Publications/Books", "uri": "dmoz/Shopping/Publications/Books", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 541, "label": "dmoz/Recreation/Humor/Useless Pages", "uri": "dmoz/Recreation/Humor/Useless_Pages", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-18", "uri": "711872290", "source": {"id": "19163", "title": "TSJSports.com | Breaking Sports News and Analysis | @TSJ_Sports", "uri": "thasportsjunkies101.com"}, "url": "http://www.thasportsjunkies101.com/wrestling-news/wwe/wwe-book-summerslam-2017-predictions", "body": "Okay, folks. It's that time of year again! One of the greatest events of the summer is finally within reach. This year, WWE's SummerSlam will be held at the Barclays Center in Brooklyn, New York. The event takes place on August 20, putting the excitement just a mere two days away. This year, the show has a fully stacked match card.\n\nSo, are you excited?\n\nWith as much criticism as the WWE has been faced with recently, I really think this show is going to deliver. Still, I often find myself thinking \"hmm...\" during outcomes that I don't necessarily agree with. Many of us joke about how we would write the show. So, I decided to do just that. I've also included some of the predictions out there, but mainly I'm sticking to how I think SummerSlam ought to be presented.\n\nFirst off, I can't help but wonder why the Hardyz are paired with JJ. With Jordan in a strange storyline involving Kurt Angle as his father, shouldn't he be doing something more? It makes sense that Angle would favor Jason Jordan and give him opportunities for no reason. If I were writing for this, I would do exactly that.\n\nNonetheless, I think that the Miz is stellar with anyone in the ring, and he'll probably put on a good show with Jordan. Hopefully, this leads to a nice feud between Jason Jordan and Miz, because I'm certain that the chemistry between them would blow the roof off from any establishment. That being said, Kurt Angle should eventually involve himself in the feud, ultimately leading to a JJ intercontinental championship run.\n\nPrediction: Jason Jordan and the Hardyz\n\nI just don't know about this one. Neville has proven to be leaps and bounds ahead of his colleagues, and maybe even is ready to return to the main roster. And while Tozawa has improved greatly in the recent weeks, the cruiserweight division as a whole is just very weak.\n\nWhen the WWE took the belt off from Neville this last Friday, it was definitely a \"hmmm...\" moment for me. I'm not really convinced that Tozawa can carry the division the same way that Neville has. That being said, I fully expect and would personally book Neville to win the belt back in a cheap fashion. Then, as punishment for the cheap win, he ought to put up the belt at a later pay-per-view against many other superstars. Or, perhaps a battle royal to name a number one contender for Neville. That way, the WWE would be able to develop other feuds as well as introduce new, fresh faces. I'm lookin' at you, Enzo Amore!\n\nPrediction: Neville wins the belt via roll-up or other controversial way.\n\nSince the card is already super-stacked, it's no surprise that the WWE moved this stellar match to the pre-show. Sad as it is, it will enable the superstars to really showcase the things that they can do. The New Day is so over with fans right now that they don't necessarily need the belts. I'm hoping to see the Usos take this one, mostly because I would love to see them eventually drop them to a different face team. You know the one. Yes, I'm thinking Breezango ought to have a short run with the belts at some point. Until that happens, the Usos and New Day work well together, and can continue their feud for awhile.\n\nPerhaps in the meantime, the WWE can get their tag-team division going one again.\n\nPrediction: The Usos win the belts.\n\nI hate the shark cage idea. So, so much. It worked fine for the Authors of Pain in NXT, and it was watchable with Chris Jericho suspended up in the air. Still, something like this shouldn't be utilized three times in less than a year. Cass has proven he can handle Show. He's smashed Enzo's face in plenty of times.\n\nIf this match has to happen, I guess I'd have Enzo try to help out Big Show and drop him down a weapon to be intercepted by Cass. But since that happened with Kevin Owens and Jericho (kind of), that's just repetitive and nobody wants to see that. But then again, who wants to see this match at all?\n\nMy hope is that Gallows and Anderson continue to align themselves with Cass. Once Enzo's let out of the cage, I would want the three to go after the little guy. That way, maybe the WWE would redirect Enzo Amore to 205 Live. It might be a decent way to write him off of the main roster, which has been in the talks for the last few weeks.\n\nPrediction: Big Cass wins.\n\nFriends, this is lazy writing at it's finest. Randy Orton is finished with Jinder Mahal, and now he's moved on. But why? That's exactly it: the WWE hasn't given us a reason to look forward to this match. Not only do I not care who wins, I also don't understand what the stakes are. Is it because they just don't like each other?\n\nThe only way to make this match relevant is to give the two men plenty of time and a nice, lengthy bout. I'd love to see Lana get herself involved, too. Maybe we can even have Orton take an intimidating step towards her...a glimpse into an old gimmick that just worked for him. Orton needs to get back to his heel roots.\n\nRusev could be a fantastic mid-card mainstay, but instead, he hasn't done much. With the right match and feud, Rusev could be shot to the level he is capable of.\n\nPrediction: Rusev wins.\n\nUnfortunately for Naomi, her run as champ has been underwhelming. There's been rumors that the WWE and Mattel are in cahoots to make a toy version of her light-up belt. In order to properly market the item, it only makes sense for Naomi to continue to be champion. However, there have been reports that the toy belt won't be ready in time for Christmas. Maybe, then, the WWE wont look at this as a marketing scheme and make a logical choice.\n\nGIVE NATALYA A CHANCE. Natalya hasn't held gold in forever. She's one of the most legitimate women in the ring, and putting the belt on her for now makes sense. She's earned it, and she sure deserves it. That being said, a lot of people think it's time for Carmella to cash in her briefcase. And, yeah, the WWE hasn't done well with surprises lately. It seems too obvious, which is why I think they will do that. It would be a good way to set up Carmella and Natalya in a feud, anyway.\n\nBut if I could, I'd keep the belt on Natalya for awhile. Carmella is fine as she is now, but I think she could be even better. Hopefully she drops James Ellsworth, too....\n\nPrediction: Natalya wins the belt.\n\nI don't know about this one, either. Why in the world did WWE give Baron the briefcase if they weren't confident that he could deliver? I don't hate Baron Corbin, but he's not really ready for a title. Then again, neither was Jinder Mahal, and that didn't really stop the company from forging the path.\n\nLuckily, John Cena had some part do with Corbin's failed cash-in. That gives some necessary buzz to the match, because I think Baron Corbin will absolutely brutalize John Cena. I don't foresee the Lone Wolf winning at SummerSlam, but I so wish that he would. Picture a bloody John Cena in the middle of the ring. Now, picture the gorgeous Nikki Bella at ringside, looking like she's going to cry. And now, picture Baron Corbin looking at her and laughing as he stands over Cena's body. Heel status? Over 9000.\n\nWishful thinking. But, nonetheless, I think Baron Corbin is receiving some kind of punishment from officials here. Expect the shovel to come out. #buried\n\nPrediction: John Cena wins.\n\nI so hated this feud at first. But then, Bray Wyatt does what he always does. He gets crazy and drops blood buckets on people's heads.\n\nOkay, so he doesn't do that all the time. But he did it to Finn Balor, which guaranteed the return of the \"demon\" persona that has been totally ignored since his return. So far, Bray has won the psychological warfare between the two.\n\nBut once the Demon Finn Balor appears, all of that is going to change. Maybe the two should conclude the match with shaking hands or something, because they are totally on the same page. But in my world, I would do something way more interesting.\n\nNow, what I would love to see Bray Wyatt to finally introduce the Sister Abigail character. If he's going to lose, have it be based off from a distraction of sorts. A creepy, ghost-like figure outside the ring, perhaps? Even if she isn't a real person immediately (as there are plenty of women running through the Mae Young Classic right now), it would help recharge his character. Start with vignettes and attacks and really build the intrigue. Not to mention, bringing in a manager-like role for him could get him the upper hand in the future. Sister Abigail should be along with her kayfabe brother at WrestleMania, for sure.\n\nAgain, wishful thinking, as Finn Balor is probably going to take this one, clean as a whistle.\n\nPrediction: Finn Balor wins.\n\nSheamus and Cesaro have been fantastic together, especially following their heel turn. With Matt and Jeff Hardy out of the picture for now, they've been running the division on the red brand. Meanwhile, Dean and Seth haven't exactly been on the same page.\n\nStill, we've all been dying to see a Shield reunion, and we kind of have one. Even though they probably won't last for long before the cracks begin in the foundation, I'm willing to enjoy the ride for now. I predict a Dean Ambrose heel turn coming up, because his gimmick has gotten super-stale. What I'd love is for both men to turn heel and act as enforcers as they used to. Remember when they worked alongside CM Punk? Good times.\n\nI don't foresee Roman Reigns joining in on this party, though, because it looks like the WWE is still busy pushing him to the moon. Too bad, because it might have worked to reform them completely. If the Shield can't get Roman Reigns over, I'm not sure anything else can.\n\nPrediction: Dean Ambrose and Seth Rollins win the titles.\n\nIn a perfect world, Alexa Bliss would have the title forever. That's not going to happen. Sasha Banks deserves time to shine here, and it's going to be a lengthy title run. Now, here, two things could happen. Sasha Banks defends her title against Nia Jax, only to have Alexa turn on her \"Team Rude\" partner (or vice-versa, establishing Bliss as a face.)\n\nWith Bayley out of the picture for a while, hopefully Sasha Banks can establish herself as a heel once again. As a babyface, she's boring. On the bright side, working with Alexa Bliss has brought out some spark in Banks.\n\nSide note: I really miss Paige. She could bring awesome diversity to the roster.\n\nAnother side note: Is there a rule that says Carmella can't cash in on a RAW superstar? Because that would be stellar if she cashed in on Banks. Just saying. Not to mention, it'd put her on the road with real-life boyfriend, Big Cass.\n\nPrediction: Sasha Banks wins the title.\n\nI love both competitors, and I love this match. I think that if the WWE wants Kevin Owens to square off against Shane McMahon, though, he should definitely lose this match. Maybe Shane misses a crucial call, which sets off the eventual match between the two. I mean, Survivor Series is right around the corner.\n\nBut what's more, is the possibility of including Shinsuke Nakamura into the US title picture. We could finally see the showdown we want between the two men. So, obviously, AJ Styles needs to retain.\n\nPrediction: AJ Styles retains the belt.\n\nWith the WWE heading to tour in India soon, this is a no-brainer. Right?\n\nThat's what I think, too. Fans are going to go crazy when they find out Nakamura lost to Jinder. But I can almost be certain that's how it's going to go. Let's face it: With Corbin's failed cash-in, I think the WWE is at a loss for another potential candidate...at least for now. Logically, that means they're going to keep the title on Jinder Mahal.\n\nI expect to see the Singh Brothers here, and if I were writing the show for the night, I'd include them as well. I don't think Jinder will win because of their interference, though. He needs to squeak out a V against the King of Strong Style.\n\nI would totally love to see Sami Zayn be the reason Shinsuke fails to capture the title. Heel Sami might be interesting, and if you didn't see Sami Zayn and Nakamura duke it out in NXT, you should probably go watch that. Who wouldn't want to see another round?\n\nIn the long run, the WWE needs to begin grooming someone to take the title off from Mahal. Otherwise, we're going to see a John Cena 17th world title run. Let's be real: WWE loves to use their \"safe guys\" when they're uncertain.\n\nAnd, again, I fully expect Shinsuke Nakamura to defeat AJ Styles for the US Championship at WrestleMania next year.\n\nPrediction: Jinder Mahal retains the title.\n\nThe stipulation here is far too convenient for Brock Lesnar to lose. Sorry, guys.\n\nSee, if Brock loses, he and Paul Heyman leave the WWE. With the hype of a Lesnar-Jones fight in the UFC, it isn't a surprise that the WWE is going to capitalize on that. People are going to watch this match simply to find out if Brock goes back to the octagon.\n\nI expect this match to be freakin' ridiculous. I mean, brutal. With tons of insane spots and blood and suplexes. I would like to see Brock Lesnar drop the belt, because without a regular champion around, the belt doesn't feel very important. In the meantime, Roman and Strowman are busy killing each other. Samoa Joe has held his own, too.\n\nAlthough I think that the Beast Incarnate is going to hang on to the strap, I would book things way differently. First idea? Play the Undertaker's gong right before a victory. Seeing the Dead Man go out on his back didn't seem real or fair. He's got heat with both Brock and Roman, anyways. I'd like to see all three of them in a title match at next year's WrestleMania. After all, he lost in New Orleans once to Lesnar. He really ought to go out riding high, retiring completely after winning the Universal championship in 2018.\n\nOr, I would do something totally unheard of. I'd have Paul Heyman screw Brock over. Nobody in the world would expect that, anyways. Heyman has been trying to push for a Samoa Joe title run, so maybe aligning Joe with the mouthpiece would be a good move? But, then again, that would guarantee that Brock Lesnar disappears. But wouldn't that mean that Heyman does, too?\n\nAlright, so that's all from me! Please, feel free to leave a comment below on what you would do if you were a writer. Which match are you most looking forward to? Do you think my predictions are totally off, or spot on? {"id": "9184889", "categories": [{"id": 111, "label": "dmoz/Arts/Television", "uri": "dmoz/Arts/Television", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 116, "label": "dmoz/Society/People/Generations and Age Groups", "uri": "dmoz/Society/People/Generations_and_Age_Groups", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 212, "label": "dmoz/Arts/Television/Programs", "uri": "dmoz/Arts/Television/Programs", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 552, "label": "dmoz/Shopping/Jewelry/Watches", "uri": "dmoz/Shopping/Jewelry/Watches", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 553, "label": "dmoz/Business/Consumer Goods and Services/Jewelry", "uri": "dmoz/Business/Consumer_Goods_and_Services/Jewelry", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 596, "label": "dmoz/Arts/Radio/Formats", "uri": "dmoz/Arts/Radio/Formats", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 1284, "label": "dmoz/Arts/Performing Arts/Hypnotism", "uri": "dmoz/Arts/Performing_Arts/Hypnotism", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-15", "uri": "709509457", "source": {"id": "989", "title": "Wrestling Inc", "uri": "wrestlinginc.com"}, "url": "http://www.WrestlingInc.com/wi/news/2017/0814/630121/braun-strowman-on-relationship-with-vince-mcmahon/", "body": "Braun Strowman spoke with TV Insider on a number of wrestling topics. Here are some of the highlights:\n\n\"That is one of my most special matches to date. To go out there and do what Big Show and I did together. I will go out on a limb and say you will never see anything like that again in this business. That's because there are no more men like us in this business. We are the last of a dying breed. I'm keeping the big man alive in the business and evolving it into what you are seeing now with the Braun Strowman character. I showed the world a glimpse, because you guys have only seen a glimpse of what I'm capable of doing. It was a big moment for me going out there and having that kind of match with Big Show.\"\n\nRelationship with Vince McMahon:\n\n\"Vince has been adamant that everything I do be spot-on, and when it's not, I know. That's part of the reason I take pride in what I do and give 100 percent of what I am capable of giving. That's because I know that not only are there millions of fans watching to make sure I'm doing what I'm supposed to be doing, but the boss himself is watching, too. He is so hands-on and wants me to be a peak performance at all times.\"\n\n\"Just to share the ring with guys like Brock [Lesnar], [Samoa] Joe and [Roman] Reigns. They have all been doing this a lot longer than I have. They have been around the world and done it all. To be able to be in the main event of SummerSlam, about two years to the day when I debuted on Monday Night Raw. If that doesn't speak for itself. Both the Raw and Smackdown rosters will compete in this gigantic event boasting a ton of matches, including a couple with hilarious/awesome stipulations. Summerslam returns to the Barclays Center in Brooklyn, New York on Sunday, August 20. The Kickoff show begins at 5 PM ET/2 PM PT, with the main card starting at 7 PM ET/4 PM PT. Here are the details on the 12 matches taking place during the event.\n\nAs of the time of this writing, there's been no indication of which matches will be on the Kickoff show.\n\nIt's the battle of the Bigs! Enzo Amore and Big Cass are no longer a tag team, and Enzo found a new giant in his life, the Big Show. The two big men will go at it, with Enzo hanging above the ring in a shark cage because over the past year, WWE has enjoyed locking people in cages: Enzo Amore, Chris Jericho, and Paul Ellering. Having someone charismatic or eccentric hanging above the ring inside a shark cage always adds a new level of entertainment to a match.\n\nSince the split between Cass and Enzo, the push seems to be more on Cass than anything else. It feels like Enzo has to have someone bigger than him to fight his battles, and let's be honest, this is all just a move to separate Cass and Enzo to legitimize Cass's solo career. I'm giving the win to Cass.\n\nNeville continues to prove why he's the king of the cruiserweights, but he has a tough task ahead of him as he takes on Akria Tozawa. During a recent episode of Raw, Tozawa won the title from Neville, so Summerslam will be their rematch.\n\n205 Live and the cruiserweight division don't have the audience attention that WWE wants, but it's hard to deny that the talent's PPV matches have been some of the best at each event. This match won't be any different, and while Neville has been a dominant champion, it's time for someone else to have a run. I'm giving the win to Tozawa.\n\nYou can't have a major PPV without John Cena, right? The unseeable man takes on the former Money in the Bank contract winner Baron Corbin for Summerslam. They both want to be WWE Champion, but apparently, they have to fight each other first.\n\nCorbin lost his contract stating he can face the champion any time he wants, so he really needs to win this fight if he wants to get another shot. However, he's up against John Cena, and he's unbeatable at major PPVs.\n\nDean Ambrose and Seth Rollins are a team once again, after each star had their run-ins with the Raw tag team champions. It's been a slow road to get to this point, but fans should be pleased. The only confusing part about this is that they're getting a chance to win the titles so quickly.\n\nThis was one of the final matches added to the already stacked card for Summerslam, and because of that, I don't think there's going to be a title change here. There may be a lot of people excited for two-thirds of the Shield reuniting, but there aren't enough people behind this angle to make a title change worth it.\n\nSmackdown stars Randy Orton and Rusev don't have much to do at this PPV, especially since Jinder Mahal bested Orton numerous times over the past few months, so now, they're going to fight each other. There isn't a lot to dig into with this storyline since it's new and feels a bit forced.\n\nBoth of these stars have been on the losing end of the stick in their past storylines. Orton lost the title and his rematches to Mahal, and Rusev lost his Battleground Flag Match to John Cena. As much as I'm pulling for Rusev, I think Orton will come out on top, driving Rusev further down the spiral of frustration and insanity.\n\nRaw's under utilized and under-appreciated talent is squaring-off at Summerslam. The two have been involved in their current storyline for the past month, and Wyatt wants to prove that Balor isn't what he used to be before he got injured. Now, after Wyatt dumped a bunch of blood on his PPV opponent, Balor has stated his alter-ego The Demon will make an appearance.\n\nThis match has the potential to be a barn burner. Sadly, it's a bit overshadowed by this incredibly stacked card. Either way, it doesn't matter who wins this match because both of the stars are fan favorites and have a ton of talent. Regardless, I have to pick a winner, so I'm going with Finn Balor because The Demon is returning.\n\nOn a recent episode of Raw, Sasha Banks beat Nia Jax to become the number one contender for the Raw Women's Championship. Now, the two will battle at Summerslam in what should be an incredible match.\n\nSasha Banks is a phenomenal performer and one of my favorites on Raw. However, there is a much larger part of me that wants to see Bliss face Jax for the title at a future event, and because of this, I'm giving the win to Bliss. Yes, this is all based on what match I want to see in the future.\n\nNaomi has proven to be a dominant champion; however, she'll be taking on Natalya, who beat five other stars at Battleground to earn the right for the championship match.\n\nWhen it comes to the women on Smackdown, there is a lot of talent and potential for great champions, and while Natalya is a a dominating force with a ton of experience, she won't win this one. I feel like Naomi is on another level right now, and the Queen of Harts won't win this battle. Personally, I'd love to see Naomi take on Becky Lynch or Asuka for the championship.\n\nThe New Day and Usos rivalry continues into SummerSlam. These two teams are the tag team division currently, since Breezango is busy solving mysteries and feuding with Arn Anderson. We're going to get an entertaining match between two fantastic teams that are at the top of their game here, and that's all that matters.\n\nAs much as I want to see the New Day come out on top, The Usos have been fantastic tag team champions, and I'd like to see this storyline continue, and Jimmy and Jey need to win in order for that to happen.\n\nThe United States Championship has been passed back and forth between AJ Styles and Kevin Owens the past month, and each time, there have been shenanigans on the refereeing side of things. In order to keep things fair and honest, Smackdown General Manager Shane McMahon will be calling the match.\n\nEverything about this match seems set up in AJ's favor. Sure, he and Shane had a match against each other earlier this year, but it seems like something is going to swing in favor for Kevin Owens. Because of this, I'm giving the win to KO.\n\nShinsuke Nakamura beat John Cena for the right to take on Jinder Mahal at Summerslam. This PPV marks the start of their battle against each other, assuming this rivalry continues after the match.\n\nWe have two fighters with two very different styles of fighting, so this will be an interesting one to watch. However, after Mahal beat Orton time and time again, he still needs to be established as a fighting champion, and because of this, I think Mahal is going to end up retaining his title.\n\nClosing the evening is Raw's top talent taking on Brock Lesnar for the Universal Championship. Samoa Joe and Lesnar already have a history and Roman Reigns, and Braun Strowman almost killed each other at the last Raw PPV. That being said, this is going to be a brutal match to watch.\n\nThis is the only match of the evening where I could see the decision going to any of the competitors. However, for the sake of what I'd like to see, I'm giving the win to Samoa Joe because I want a fighting champion, not just someone who feels part-time. {"id": "9928987", "categories": [{"id": 96, "label": "dmoz/Arts/Music/Instruments", "uri": "dmoz/Arts/Music/Instruments", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 297, "label": "dmoz/Science/Social Sciences/Psychology", "uri": "dmoz/Science/Social_Sciences/Psychology", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 539, "label": "dmoz/Sports/Soccer/News and Media", "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Soccer/News_and_Media", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 954, "label": "dmoz/Shopping/Jewelry/Wedding", "uri": "dmoz/Shopping/Jewelry/Wedding", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 1058, "label": "dmoz/Recreation/Collecting/Toys", "uri": "dmoz/Recreation/Collecting/Toys", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-18", "uri": "711531137", "source": {"id": "1185", "title": "The Times of India", "uri": "timesofindia.indiatimes.com"}, "url": "http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/sports/wwe/top-stories/samoa-joe-talks-highly-of-brock-lesnar/articleshow/60121875.cms", "body": "The impact Samoa Joe has made ever since debuting in the WWE main roster has been huge and a big part of the 'legend' of Samoa Joe growing in the company and among the fans, was him standing toe-to-toe with the Beast Incarnate Brock Lesnar himself. The impact Samoa Joe has made ever since debuting in the WWE main roster has been huge and a big part of the 'legend' of Samoa Joe growing in the company and among the fans, was him standing toe-to-toe with the Beast Incarnate Brock Lesnar himself.\n\nA legitimate superstar before he joined WWE, Joe has taken little time in WWE making fans believe in him and after a stellar 'Great Balls of Fire' main event with Lesnar, Joe finds himself in the middle of one of the biggest matches in SummeSlam history - a fatal-four way for the Universal Champion against champion Lesnar, Roman Reigns and Braun Strowman. And on top of that, Joe walks in to his first SummerSlam as the outright favourite to dethrone the Beast Incarnate.\n\nAhead of the mega-event, Joe talked about the big opportunity, his match with Lesnar at GBOF and Wrestlemania.\n\nAim at SummerSlam:\n\nThe sole goal is to go in there and walk out with the championship gold. I will be aiming to do that at SummerSlam. I don't see myself not walking out of SummerSlam as the universal champion. Universal Championship is my focus and I plan on having it. In the long term, I will hold to the champions as long as possible. I have a build on career holding record title reigns and I will do it here as well.\n\nAbout his opponents:\n\nIt is like asking what kind of poison you want to have for dinner. Each one have their own attributes and issues. But the biggest thing for me is to keep my head on a swivel and be aware. The most dangerous will obviously be Brock, the champion, and we have unfinished business as well.\n\nWhen you have so many forces of the nature in the ring, sometimes you have ride up the storm and see them collide and take the opportunity. I did that in fatal-five way; I am smarter than the other guys in the ring.\n\nOn facing Brock Lesnar at Great Balls of Fire Great balls:\n\nAside from the result, it was every bit the physical match that I expected it to be. Brock is one of those special athletes and the stakes and what happens in the ring is elevated in his presence. I consider myself an intense individual, and I have no qualms to say he lived up to his hype as a very intense individual and it was fierce. I think the match lived up to the expectations.\n\nOn being booked as a legitimate threat to Lensar's title:\n\nIt was because Brock sees it that way. He sees me as capable enough and someone who can get it done in the ring. It is a false assumption that he is really tone-deaf to the rest of the world, but he really is one of the most savvy businessmen in our industry, if not all of combat sports. He knew what he was getting into and he understood the magnitude and what kind of threat I presented to him. Him being convinced lend more fire and hype leading up to the match.\n\nExpectations from Wrestlemania 34:\n\nWhen it comes to Wrestlemania I will take whatever opportunity that comes to me. I would love to take on somebody like Brock, Roman, Seth (Rollins), Dean (Ambrose) (Finn) Balor, (AJ) Styles, (John) Cena, the list is endless. you put anyone of them in front of me and I will be good to go.\n\nBiggest change coming in to WWE:\n\nThe scale of everything here is amped up to the 10h power. The production here is top notch and it is the job that they do week after week which is astonishing. They raise the stakes when it comes to big matches.\n\nDream match:\n\nI think talking about dream match, when we just scratch the surface and what is out there right now, Cena, Orton, Balor, Styles - these are guys I have been in ring with before and then there are guys I know we can get in to the ring together and can get the lights outs. it is easier at this point in time to say who isn't a dream match rather than who is, because there are so many guys I have not crossed path with.
