{"id": "9979583", "categories": [{"id": 111, "label": "dmoz/Arts/Television", "uri": "dmoz/Arts/Television", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 212, "label": "dmoz/Arts/Television/Programs", "uri": "dmoz/Arts/Television/Programs", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 1184, "label": "dmoz/Sports/Wrestling/Professional", "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Wrestling/Professional", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-18", "uri": "711668767", "source": {"id": "10880", "title": "Wrestlezone", "uri": "wrestlezone.com"}, "url": "http://www.wrestlezone.com/news/874741-jinder-mahal-on-when-he-found-out-he-was-winning-the-wwe-title-pressure-of-being-the-man-fans-who-dont-accept-him-as-champion", "body": "(Photo by Foto24/Gallo Images/Getty Images)\n\nAhead of his Title match at SummerSlam on Sunday night, WWE Champion Jinder Mahal recently spoke with WZ Live Tweeter Joshua Caudill of CraveOnline.com, and below are some interview highlights:\n\nOn winning the title at WWE Backlash in May:\n\n\"I wasn't actually expecting to take the championship that match,\" Mahal said. \"I think it was a moment that really shocked the WWE Universe. Right after I won the championship, they showed some of the faces in the crowd and their jaws were hitting the floor [laughs]. That was kind of my reaction when I found out.\"\n\nMahal added he didn't find out he was winning the WWE title until right before the match.\n\nOn the newfound pressure that comes with being WWE Champion:\n\n\"Now I keep track of what the gates are and the live shows and how everything is going in that sense and there is pressure to close up the show every night but pressure creates diamonds so I'm embracing it,\" Mahal said. \"When I won the title, I couldn't really celebrate or take it easy because I knew that I was going to have to step it up even more to go down in history as one of the greatest champions of all-time. That's my goal now and to become a multiple time champion. I want to be a 10-time WWE Champion.\"\n\nOn fans who have yet to embrace the idea of Jinder Mahal as WWE Champion:\n\n\"Sometimes you feel like a performer's first title run you don't really see them as a champion. I remember when I was a kid and when Chris Jericho won the championship, I was like, \"Really? Chris Jericho beat Triple H and The Rock?' Mahal said. \"But now Chris Jericho is one of the all-time greats and he's in the same league as Triple H and The Rock, in my opinion. I just want to solidify myself as WWE Champion material and main event status. I want to main event WrestleMania.\"", "dateTime": "2017-08-18T17:54:00Z", "extractedDates": null, "sim": 0.5921568870544434, "dateCrawl": "2017-08-18", "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3365109", "time": "17:54:00", "lang": "eng", "eventUri": "eng-3364258", "location": null, "concepts": [{"id": "305090", "type": "org", "label": {"eng": "Getty Images"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Getty_Images", "score": 4}, {"id": "307120", "type": "wiki", "label": {"eng": "Face (professional wrestling)"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Face_(professional_wrestling)", "score": 3}, {"id": "315017", "type": "org", "label": {"eng": "WWE"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WWE", "score": 5}, {"id": "332488", "type": "person", "label": {"eng": "Triple H"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Triple_H", "score": 1}, {"id": "340566", "type": "wiki", "label": {"eng": "World Heavyweight Championship (WWE)"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Heavyweight_Championship_(WWE)", "score": 5}, {"id": "365538", "type": "person", "label": {"eng": "Chris Jericho"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chris_Jericho", "score": 2}, {"id": "426499", "type": "person", "label": {"eng": "Jinder Mahal"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jinder_Mahal", "score": 4}, {"id": "652290", "type": "wiki", "label": {"eng": "WWE Backlash"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WWE_Backlash", "score": 3}, {"id": "682446", "type": "wiki", "label": {"eng": "Dread Central"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CraveOnline", "score": 3}], "image": "http://cdn2-www.wrestlezone.com/assets/uploads/2017/04/jinder-mahal-1.jpg", "timeCrawl": "21:41:00", "isDuplicate": false, "title": "Jinder Mahal on When He Found Out He Was Winning the WWE Title, Pressure of Being \"The Man\", Fans Who Don't Accept Him as Champion", "originalArticle": null}
{"id": "9979584", "categories": [{"id": 244, "label": "dmoz/Shopping/Publications/Books", "uri": "dmoz/Shopping/Publications/Books", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 338, "label": "dmoz/Arts/Genres", "uri": "dmoz/Arts/Genres", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 339, "label": "dmoz/Arts/Genres/Science Fiction and Fantasy", "uri": "dmoz/Arts/Genres/Science_Fiction_and_Fantasy", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 383, "label": "dmoz/Sports/Fantasy", "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Fantasy", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 829, "label": "dmoz/Sports/Fantasy/Football", "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Fantasy/Football", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 1055, "label": "dmoz/Sports/Wrestling", "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Wrestling", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 1056, "label": "dmoz/Sports/Wrestling/Amateur", "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Wrestling/Amateur", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 1184, "label": "dmoz/Sports/Wrestling/Professional", "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Wrestling/Professional", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 1500, "label": "dmoz/Shopping/Visual Arts/Thematic", "uri": "dmoz/Shopping/Visual_Arts/Thematic", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-18", "uri": "711668749", "source": {"id": "18904", "title": "The Ringer", "uri": "theringer.com"}, "url": "https://www.theringer.com/sports/2017/8/18/16169080/summerslam-2017-preview", "body": "Wrestling fans are getting what they want at a greater rate than ever -- so why do they feel like they're always being worked? This weekend's pay-per-view could hold the answer.\n\nPro wrestling is fantasy. It's not sword-and-sorcery, but it's fantasy nonetheless. And while no one (present company excepted) would accuse WWE of wielding metaphor as a weapon in the manner that epic fantasy sometimes does, it reflects our culture in a much more insidious manner, putting on a sideshow mirror version of our ids and superegos, our visceral angst, in the form of campy brawling. If at times I have read too much into the meaning of pro wrestling, it's because (1) the art inherently asks as much of the audience as the performers, and (2) because I want it to be more than it is.\n\nThat, in a nutshell, is the plight of the wrestling fan, and the reason the source of our great disappointment is our own expectations. Wrestling doesn't have the prestige of scripted television or the plausible deniability of real sports, and so our confidence as fans in the product is inherently skewed. We want it to be better, and it's always easy enough to imagine a better way forward -- or what seems like one, anyway.\n\nOn my podcast last week, I fantasy-booked an ending to SummerSlam. It wasn't brilliant, but it made a perfect sort of sense. Frankly, I wish I hadn't said it, because now I'm the tout who predicted the long-shot win, and anything else will be a disappointment. That's not quite the right metaphor, though, because fantasy booking isn't predicting the outcome of pro wrestling -- it's hoping for it. It's a second-level meta-contest between the WWE creative team and fans who think they can do it better. [Ahem.] We'll get to my proposal in a second, but first a bit of background.\n\nFour years ago, the Shield -- Roman Reigns, Seth Rollins, and Dean Ambrose -- were the most popular faction in WWE. They split up when Seth Rollins joined the Authority, the evil establishment group. Seth went the way of evil; Ambrose put on jeans and began a Steve Austin-lite comedic run; and Reigns kept the trappings (and, theoretically, the mystique) of the Shield and was shoved into the main event spotlight. Since then, Rollins got hurt and turned babyface; Ambrose won the WWE championship, lost it, and fizzled, or vice versa; and Reigns became the most contemptible \"star\" of the company since John Cena at his \"Cena Sucks\" peak. All of this bears mention because two of the most popular fantasy-booking ideas are (1) a three-way battle between the former Shieldsters for the title, and, more importantly, (2) the reunion of the Shield. In the present, Ambrose and Rollins (who battled extensively after their breakup) have formed an uneasy alliance to go after the Raw tag titles, currently held by Sheamus and Cesaro. Meanwhile, Reigns is one of four -- along with Brock Lesnar, Braun Strowman, and Samoa Joe -- wrestlers contending for the WWE Universal title.\n\nSo here's my pitch: Rollins and Ambrose win, and the crowd goes wild. Then, in the main event, they interfere to help Reigns win the title, and the Brooklyn crowd turns on them, reforming the Shield as the biggest heel faction this side of the nWo. As good as he quietly has become, Reigns is symbolic of WWE's inorganic booking decisions, and the crowd has fully turned on him. (And to his credit, he's embraced the hate in a way Cena never fully did.) If he were to win on Sunday, the audience would boo the show into oblivion. If Rollins and Ambrose -- who have themselves both failed to find their footing as headline babyfaces -- helped him, the fans would still flip out. But instead of booing WWE, as they'd be doing if Reigns won clean, they'd be booing Rollins and Ambrose for abetting the win fans were dreading. They'd be booing WWE's newest heel faction. The SummerSlam crowd would be throwing trash like it was Bash at the Beach '96. Instead of going home disenchanted, we'd be going home angry.\n\nThat's good booking. Or at least, I think so. And of course I do, because it's my idea.\n\nThis is the real problem with fantasy booking. Reality can never meet the expectations of imagination. If 100 Reddit commenters have better ideas for how Jon Snow should get to Eastwatch, they could never agree on a replacement, and yet they'll all be disappointed in what happens on Game of Thrones this week. It's not a knock on fandom -- it's one of the perils of consciousness. If you care enough about something, it's easy to talk yourself into hating it. This has become the core of wrestling fandom. It's like that saying -- the opposite of love isn't hate; it's going out to a bar on Monday night without caring that your DVR is broken.\n\nBut sometimes, reality has a way of fantasy booking on its own. Take Sunday's Raw women's championship match between Alexa Bliss and Sasha Banks. A month ago, Bayley won the right to challenge Bliss for the belt. Bayley's run on Raw has been a dud since she debuted last July. She rose to renown in NXT as the underdog who finally made it to the top, but she was introduced on Raw as a conquering hero. With her hugs, side ponytail, neon colorways, and nuclear earnestness, she's a magnet for the young girl demo, and she should have a firm place in WWE. But the company should have run back the underdog story line and made her earn her fandom on the main roster, because as Daniel Bryan she's fantastic, but as the Ultimate Warrior she's been a dull thud.\n\nWhen Bayley won the no. 1 contendership, it felt like there had to be another shoe to drop -- not only was Bayley's mediocrity apparent, but we were a mere month removed from a very good battle between Bliss and Banks at Great Balls of Fire that begged for a rematch. Apparently WWE wasn't planning for a sequel, but when Bayley hurt her shoulder during a collision with the ring apron, it was forced to scramble, putting the title shot up for grabs in a tournament of all the women on Raw, and Banks came out on top. It's like the universe heard the message boards groan and corrected course.\n\nIt's not always the universe making changes, though -- sometimes it's WWE. WWE bigwigs like to say that they can test-market their product five nights a week -- every time they put on a show in front of an audience. And even though it can seem like they're hearing what they want to hear, sometimes they respond to crowd boredom. (It should be said that the difference between what WWE hears and what it seems like fans want has a lot to do with the difference between the more forgiving fans at house shows and the snarky ones at Monday Night Raw, though that doesn't change the perception for the at-home viewer that WWE's pet projects are poorly received.) On Monday, WWE added a broken hand to the broken Big Show-Big Cass feud; swapped the cruiserweight title from Neville to challenger Akira Tozawa, giving some much-needed heat to what was already a rematch from a month ago; and raised the stakes (or the gore, anyway) of Finn B\u00e1lor vs. Bray Wyatt when the latter dumped a \"viscous acidic liquid of some sort\" -- fake blood by literally any other name -- over the former's head.\n\nOver on SmackDown, the main event picture -- previously occupied by a Randy Orton-Jinder Mahal feud that felt like a months-long Aristocrats routine, but with the Great Khali instead of scatology -- has been reinvigorated by the return of John Cena and the absolutely unthinkable ouster of Cena by newcomer Shinsuke Nakamura. When Nakamura takes on Mahal on Sunday for the WWE championship, and Cena deigns to give a platform to Baron Corbin, match quality will take a backseat to the sheer implausibility of the matchmaking. Two weeks ago, when Nakamura (legitimately) suplexed Cena onto his head, it might as well have been a metaphor for a creative team-wide concussion, because something had to be rattling around upstairs to defy expectations to such an extent. (That something is probably WWE's ongoing march into the Asian market, but it's nice to think the Reddit market is suddenly getting a fair hearing too.)\n\nOf course, for everybody who's excited that Nakamura or Banks is getting such an opportunity, there's probably someone who fantasy-booked someone else into that spot. The grating chorus of online wrestling fandom is that [insert favorite wrestler's name here] is being buried -- a.k.a. being held back irrationally by the WWE decision-makers. And even though sometimes this is true, more often than not it's a hollow argument, a way to validate general angst. And regardless, if you define \"burial\" as absence from the main event, then it's the very nature of the sport that 90 percent of the roster is getting buried at any moment. The inevitable endpoint of these arguments is that every PPV would end up with a battle royale wherein all the wrestlers that somebody somewhere likes would duke it out for the top prize. And one Royal Rumble a year is enough.\n\nAll of which is to say that the main event on Sunday's show is at its core a glorious schmozz, a test-marketed meat locker with a cow marinated for every palate. The defending champ is Brock Lesnar, the former UFC heavyweight who conveys an air of legitimacy (despite a middling attendance record) to the fake sport. His three challengers represent the separate blocs of WWE fandom: Reigns represents the kids-and-women demo, the John Cena voters; Samoa Joe represents the indie snobs and highbrow purists; and Braun Strowman is the delegate from the reptilian brain, the endlessly powerful part of wrestling fandom that never tires of muscular spectacle, growling voices, and full-on commitment to farce. (The fact that all four guys are nominally heels is beside the point. They don't need to tell us who to root for because we know who represents our tastes without them putting their sunglasses on the kid in the front row.) Vince McMahon famously detests multi-party main events, so the very fact of the four contestants makes the bout feel slightly crowd-sourced. But that's the wonder of it: it's a fantasy-booking Frankenstein's monster.\n\nThe most straightforward feud on the card is probably AJ Styles vs. Kevin Owens, and the very existence of both of them in the WWE is proof that fantasy can come true. A couple of years ago, they existed in WWE only in messageboard fantasy booking -- the kind that was so implausible that you just groaned. Now they're such a part of the fabric of WWE that Shane McMahon is the special guest referee -- a cog in the Owens-Styles machine -- and it feels perfectly normal.\n\nThat's where we are in WWE in 2017, and specifically at SummerSlam. As much as we fans love to counterprogram in our minds, this event is a pretty good representation of the hopes and dreams of the fan base. Maybe it's because we fantasy-booking types are finally the majority. If the volume of jeers that Reigns gets is any indication, \"we're all smarks now\" isn't overstatement. Maybe our fantasy is becoming reality.\n\nBut WWE still has to put on the show. And it still has to decide who wins in the end. Because it's easy enough to fantasy-book a main event match and make everyone happy -- the hard part is booking the finish. In a four-person match like this, you're going to disappoint three-quarters of the audience with whatever ending you choose. If Strowman loses, the unyielding ascent of the WWE's lovable monster hits its end in a weirdly insignificant way. If Joe loses, the strains of \"he's getting buried\" might break the internet. If Lesnar loses, he's (in story line) quitting WWE, but it's not exactly the dream match ending WWE surely had in mind when it put the belt back on him. If Reigns loses, well, that sort of makes sense.\n\nThat's why my vote is for Reigns, because a Reigns win is the only ending guaranteed to disappoint the most people. On Sunday, we'll either be cheering separately or booing together. Sometimes, the unhappy ending is the best fantasy of all.", "dateTime": "2017-08-18T15:54:00Z", "extractedDates": null, "sim": 0.5843137502670288, "dateCrawl": "2017-08-18", "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3364258", "time": "15:54:00", "lang": "eng", "eventUri": "eng-3364258", "location": null, "concepts": [{"id": "303768", "type": "wiki", "label": {"eng": "Fantasy"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fantasy", "score": 5}, {"id": "304688", "type": "wiki", "label": {"eng": "Glossary of professional wrestling terms"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Glossary_of_professional_wrestling_terms", "score": 3}, {"id": "306411", "type": "wiki", "label": {"eng": "Professional wrestling"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Professional_wrestling", "score": 5}, {"id": "306414", "type": "org", "label": {"eng": "Subreddit"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reddit", "score": 3}, {"id": "306428", "type": "wiki", "label": {"eng": "House show"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/House_show", "score": 2}, {"id": "307060", "type": "wiki", "label": {"eng": "Game of Thrones"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Game_of_Thrones", "score": 3}, {"id": "307120", "type": "wiki", "label": {"eng": "Face (professional wrestling)"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Face_(professional_wrestling)", "score": 4}, {"id": "311311", "type": "wiki", "label": {"eng": "Podcast"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Podcast", "score": 3}, {"id": "311333", "type": "wiki", "label": {"eng": "Internet forum"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet_forum", "score": 1}, {"id": "315013", "type": "person", "label": {"eng": "A.J. The event will be broadcast on pay-per-view and streamed on the WWE Network starting at 7 p.m. ET.\n\nHere are the top matches taking place at SummerSlam and our predicted winners:\n\nBrock Lesnar (champion) vs. Roman Regins vs. Samoa Joe vs. Braun Strowman in a Fatal 4-Way Match for the Universal Championship.\n\nThe most unpredictable of the matches taking place Sunday, each competitor has a fair chance at taking home Raw's top prize. Reigning champion Brock Lesnar and his advocate Paul Heyman have threatened in recent weeks to leave the WWE if The Beast loses due to the odds stacked against him. With Lesnar rumored to be headed back to the UFC for a potential fight against Jon Jones, a new champion will most likely be crowned here.\n\nDue to Samoa Joe's impressive display against Lesnar at Great Balls of Fire, The Destroyer barely edges out Reigns and Strowman as a potential winner who only needs to lock in his fabled Coquina Clutch submission maneuver onto any of the competitors to win the match.\n\nPredicted winner: Samoa Joe\n\nJinder Mahal (champion) vs. Shinsuke Nakamura for the WWE Championship\n\nDespite Shinsuke Nakamura's impressive win over John Cena recently to earn this championship match, the odds may prove too difficult for WWE's resident Rockstar to overcome as Jinder Mahal will once again be backed by his henchmen, The Singh Brothers. Always willing to do whatever it takes to win, including enlisting the help of past champions, Mahal will once again cheat his way to victory among a chorus of boos.\n\nPredicted winner: Jinder Mahal\n\nJohn Cena vs. Baron Corbin\n\nCorbin will be out for blood Cena's blood since he ruined his chance at becoming WWE Champion Tuesday on Smackdown when he cashed in his Money in the Bank contract. Cena, who has repeatedly embarrassed The Lone Wolf, keeps a busy schedule outside of WWE and may be headed toward another sabbatical. There is also the fact that Cena announced in July that he is a free agent able to compete on either Raw or Smackdown to consider as he may move onto the red brand in the near future to face new challengers. This makes Corbin the likely winner as WWE will want him to look strong as he attempts to climb back into the championship picture on Tuesday nights.\n\nPredicted winner: Baron Corbin\n\nAJ Styles (champion) vs. Kevin Owens for the United States Championship with Shane McMahon as the special guest referee\n\nA special guest referee always equals some type of shenanigans taking place in a match and this will be no different. Expect Shane McMahon to get involved physically in this bout and for the Smackdown commissioner to use his power in order to select and favor either AJ Styles or Kevin Owens to win the match. Destined to feud with the loser, and with McMahon having already faced Styles at WrestleMania, The Phenomenal One will win setting up a future confrontation between McMahon and Owens.\n\nPredicted winner: AJ Styles\n\nCesaro and Sheamus (champions) vs. Dean Ambrose and Seth Rollins for the Raw Tag Team Championship\n\nThere is no stopping this Shield reunion between Dean Ambrose and Seth Rollins that has been building up for weeks. The Hounds of Justice are back and will prove too formidable for Cesaro and Sheamus as WWE looks to bring back one the most popular factions of all time. With championship gold around their waist, perhaps afterwards Ambrose and Rollins will approach Roman Reigns about rejoining their ranks as well.\n\nPredicted winners: Dean Ambrose and Seth Rollins\n\nNaomi (champion) vs. Natalya for the Smackdown Women's Championship\n\nNaomi's feel-good championship run shows no signs of slowing down and she has yet to face the other women present on the Smackdown roster making her the favorite to win. The most exciting thing about this match, however, is that Carmella will be waiting in the wings with her Money in the Bank briefcase. There is no better time than SummerSlam for The Princess of Staten Island to cash in on a depleted Naomi and become the new Smackdown Women's Champion.\n\nPredicted winner: Naomi, followed by Carmella cashing her Money in the Bank briefcase to become the new Smackdown Women's Champion\n\nAlexa Bliss (champion) vs. Sasha Banks for the Raw Women's Championship\n\nSasha Banks is acting as a replacement here for Bayley who has been forced to miss out on SummerSlam due to injury. This makes Alexa Bliss the easy favorite to win as she moves on to feud with Nia Jax who has remained in the championship picture.\n\nPredicted winner: Alexa Bliss\n\nFinn Balor vs. Bray Wyatt\n\nBray Wyatt has awakened Finn Balor's demon persona which will be out in full force at SummerSlam much to the Eater of Worlds' dismay. After losing to Wyatt recently on Raw, Balor will come out victorious at SummerSlam, however, Sunday will serve as just the latest chapter in this feud that will continue on for at least another month.\n\nPredicted winner: Finn Balor\n\nSummerSlam will also feature Smackdown Tag Team Champions The New Day defending their titles against The Usos; Randy Orton taking on Rusev; Big Show facing off against Big Cass with Enzo Amore suspended above the ring in a shark cage; Cruiserweight Champion Akira Tozawa defending his title against Neville; and The Hardy Boyz with Jason Jordan battling Intercontinental Champion The Miz and his Miztourage.\n\nThe writing is on the wall...\n\nDon't miss @WWE @SummerSlam, streaming LIVE THIS SUNDAY at 7e/4p only on @WWENetwork! #SummerSlam pic.twitter.com/0uyLJB1RF6 -- WWE (@WWE)\n\nAugust 17, 2017", "dateTime": "2017-08-18T13:09:00Z", "extractedDates": [{"textEnd": 7, "textStart": 0, "imp": true, "date": "2017-08-18", "amb": false}, {"textEnd": 5751, "textStart": 5736, "date": "2017-08-17", "amb": false}], "sim": 0.572549045085907, "dateCrawl": "2017-08-18", "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3364258", "time": "13:09:00", "lang": "eng", "eventUri": "eng-3364258", "location": null, "concepts": [{"id": "216991", "label": {"eng": "Brooklyn"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brooklyn", "type": "loc", "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Brooklyn"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}, "score": 4}, {"id": "307120", "type": "wiki", "label": {"eng": "Face (professional wrestling)"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Face_(professional_wrestling)", "score": 3}, {"id": "307188", "type": "org", "label": {"eng": "Ultimate Fighting Championship"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ultimate_Fighting_Championship", "score": 3}, {"id": "315013", "type": "person", "label": {"eng": "A.J. Take a look below and see what the superstars of SmackDown Live have in store for Sunday.\n\nThere are two obvious questions here: First, is Styles going to retain the title he has taken from Owens twice since the beginning of July? And second, how will special guest referee Shane McMahon factor into the result?\n\nWe'll start with the second question first. Clearly there's been a good amount of build and not-so-subtle hints that McMahon, the SmackDown Commissioner by day, is willing to, uh, overstep his referee responsibilities and engage in any pugilistic activities with whoever might lay a hand on him, whether it's Owens or Styles.\n\nAlso, McMahon doesn't exactly have a history of being an impartial ref. Look no further than his antics when he refused to give Stone Cold Steve Austin the three count against Mankind at Survivor Series. Granted, that was 19 years ago, but we were starkly reminded of that by KO at SmackDown a couple of weeks ago.\n\nSo, Shane, are you going to call this one down the middle? Probably not.\n\nOwens and Styles have been intertwined in various storylines since the Superstar shakeup in April. But the real heat began at Battleground, when Owens pinned Styles for the title, only to lose it two days later. Conventional thinking suggests Styles will come out on top, with McMahon possibly playing a role in the outcome, thus setting up a feud with Owens. But as we've seen in this rivalry, nothing seems to go as planned, especially when you have titles between the two changing at house shows.\n\nJohn Cena vs. Baron Corbin\n\nNot a single person will enter SummerSlam with more regret than Corbin, not after he failed to cash in his briefcase Tuesday and walk away with gold.\n\nA devious plan to leverage his free shot for the title backfired when Corbin went to pin a seemingly down-and-out Jinder Mahal, only for the champ to collect himself and roll up Corbin for the win. Corbin was beyond angry, and the question now is whether he can maximize that anger and take it out on Cena.\n\nAs with WrestleMania, Cena will not be the star attraction at SummerSlam. Not even close. But his presence alone makes this match against Corbin that much more appealing. It's hard to imagine Cena, despite the fact that he has lost his past six SummerSlam matches, would let Corbin get over on him, especially considering that the 16-time champ just went down cleanly to Shinsuke Nakamura in a No. 1 contenders match. There's only so much beating a legend can take, right?\n\nFor Corbin, it's hard to imagine him being thrust into the championship spotlight anytime soon if he were to not only fall to Cena, but do so without a briefcase to fall back on.\n\nSmackDown tag team championship: The New Day vs. The Usos\n\nThese two teams have had tremendous chemistry lately, starting at Battleground, where The New Day won their first SmackDown tag-team titles. Even a seemingly filler match Tuesday on SmackDown was entertaining. But after their 124-day reign as champs, it seems doubtful The Usos would reclaim the titles. More bad news for Jey and Jimmy Uso: They have fallen in each of their previous three pay-per-view matches against The New Day. The only potential swerve here is if Kofi Kingston were to be a factor. On Tuesday, Daniel Bryan made it clear that Kingston would be the odd man out at SummerSlam. Hmmm.\n\nRandy Orton vs. Rusev\n\nThere's not a ton of history between Orton and Rusev, but the build between the two has been intriguing. Two weeks ago, Rusev attacked Orton as SmackDown came to a close, and just the other day, Orton landed a perfectly timed RKO on his Bulgarian opponent, and yes, it was out of nowhere.\n\nGiven an injury and long layoff after the brand shakeup, Rusev has not had a lot of TV exposure in recent months, and the one high-profile event he was in at Battleground was an underwhelming loss against John Cena.\n\nAs for Orton, he hopes he can make up for a confounding loss a year ago at SummerSlam, when Brock Lesnar busted The Viper's head open, a wound that caused the match to end prematurely. Orton hasn't won a SummerSlam match since 2013, when he cashed in his Money in the Bank briefcase to take the title from Daniel Bryan.\n\nDespite Orton's dubious numbers and Rusev's lackluster existence lately, this match is as tough to call as any on the SummerSlam card.", "dateTime": "2017-08-18T10:54:00Z", "extractedDates": null, "sim": 0.5686274766921997, "dateCrawl": "2017-08-18", {"id": "9939109", "categories": [{"id": 58, "label": "dmoz/Arts/Music", "uri": "dmoz/Arts/Music", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 59, "label": "dmoz/Arts/Music/Personal Pages", "uri": "dmoz/Arts/Music/Personal_Pages", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 114, "label": "dmoz/Arts/Performing Arts/Theatre", "uri": "dmoz/Arts/Performing_Arts/Theatre", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 686, "label": "dmoz/Arts/Music/Education", "uri": "dmoz/Arts/Music/Education", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 688, "label": "dmoz/Business/Publishing and Printing/Publishing", "uri": "dmoz/Business/Publishing_and_Printing/Publishing", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 920, "label": "dmoz/Arts/Music/Resources", "uri": "dmoz/Arts/Music/Resources", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 921, "label": "dmoz/Shopping/Music/Sheet Music", "uri": "dmoz/Shopping/Music/Sheet_Music", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 967, "label": "dmoz/Arts/Music/Composition", "uri": "dmoz/Arts/Music/Composition", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 1082, "label": "dmoz/Arts/Music/Women in Music", "uri": "dmoz/Arts/Music/Women_in_Music", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-18", "uri": "711556128", "source": {"id": "205", "title": "Mirror", "uri": "mirror.co.uk"}, "url": "http://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/other-sports/wrestling/baron-corbin-im-tailored-wwe-11012099", "body": "Get daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email\n\nWWE fans were left stunned when Baron Corbin's Money in the Bank contract cash-in on Jinder Mahal failed in spectacular fashion.\n\nThe Lone Wolf is only the third person not to become world champion when using the briefcase after interfering in SmackDown's main event.\n\nHe attacked his SummerSlam opponent John Cena - who had just hit the WWE Champion with a super AA - before preparing to take advantage.\n\nBut Cena recovered and distracted the 32-year-old, from Lenexa, Kansas, allowing Mahal to quickly roll him up for a pin and escape with his title.\n\nThe controversial booking deprived fans of a potential 'MITB moment' on Sunday, but may not be the disaster it initially looked for Corbin.\n\nThe former NFL star could yet regain the briefcase, as Mahal had a foot under the bottom rope, potentially invalidating his pinfall victory.\n\nEven if he fails to do so, the unfortunate turn of events may provide the inspiration for a furious Corbin to overcome Cena on a grand stage.\n\nAhead of the twist, Corbin spoke to the Mirror about his new theme music, facing Cena and why he is tailored to become WWE Champion.\n\nEarlier this month you debuted a new entrance song at a WWE live event in Ottawa, Canada. Can you talk us through the process of a WWE superstar getting new music and the part you play in that?\n\nYeah for sure. It's a cool process. I thought my music from NXT was really cool, but I really want to evolve. I not only want to evolve as a superstar and evolve my skills, I want to evolve every part of me. I thought new music was going to be a big part of that as I've changed a little bit since I was in NXT. I wanted something else that kind of fit me more and told a story and I think my new music really does. They put it together and came up with a few different versions and had to go back to the drawing board a couple of times, but I wanted something very special and very real to me and my new music is something that I think everybody is going to enjoy.\n\nIt's got a threatening vibe to it - something bad is going to happen when you hear this music. It's still not completely finished, I think we're going to add stuff to it, but when you hear it you will feel it and just understand 'I know what this guy is about to do, I know what he's going to do to that guy standing in the ring across from him'.\n\nDid you join CFO$ (John Paul Alicastro and Michael Conrad Lauri who create entrance music for WWE) in the studio? They created your last song, Superhuman.\n\nNo someone else did my new music, Jim Johnston [who composed entrance theme songs for WWE from 1985 to 2014, before leaving the company to work as a freelance composer] was really the biggest part of my new music. He did a lot of special things. I unfortunately didn't get to go in the studio with Jim and be a part of it, but he would send me constant updates, constant evolutions of the song and would ask me about it, I'd say 'hey it needs more rasp on the guitars' or something like that and he would do it. I had a distant involvement, but I think he made something special and iconic. It was really awesome to work with him on it.\n\nIt's such an exciting time for you, having won the Money In The Bank briefcase at the Money In The Bank pay-per-view in June, then feuded with Shinsuke Nakamura and faced him at Battleground in July. What was it like competing against him?\n\nIt was awesome, the guy has been around a long time and he has been an iconic star in Japan and now has come over to put his mark in WWE. Battleground I had to take it slow because I didn't know everything he was bringing to the table. It was a back and forth match where I had to try and stay out of distance of his striking range and he did the same with me. It was a pretty cool, interesting chess match to me and I had to do what I did at the end of it to get away from it with a disqualification! He has been an awesome guy to face because he's very strong and physical and that's what I like. He's a top tier guy so every time I can go into battle with a guy like that, it's a good time for me.\n\nTalking of top tier guys, there is nobody on a higher tier in WWE than John Cena. We saw him attack you on SmackDown to spark a new rivalry. How excited are you about the prospect of facing him, a 16-time world champion, at SummerSlam?\n\nThat would be awesome because he is the guy on the pedestal that people consider the mark - you have to go through John Cena if you want to be world champion, you have to go through John Cena if you want to be considered a top guy. He put me through a table and stuck his nose in my business when I was just going out to have a few words with Shinsuke and my words involved hitting him with the briefcase a few times, but that's not John Cena's business! I think I have a little bit of a score to settle with John. If he wants to face me at SummerSlam, I'm more than open to giving him a beating in front of that many people.\n\nI consider myself a world class athlete. Coming from the NFL, coming from grappling, boxing, all of those things tailored me to come here and become a WWE champion. Those things they coincide with it, the physicality, the footwork, the aggressive nature, the training, the diet. Coming from the NFL, I was 335lb in the NFL. You train yourself to be the best and coming to WWE I had to make some changes, I had to be a little bit quicker, a lit bit leaner, I lost 60lb, I changed my diet, I changed my workout and all those things tailored me to be WWE Champion.\n\nWhen I got in the ring with the indy darlings in NXT, the crowd hated it when I beat them up. All that does is add fuel to my fire. I enjoy and love to make people whine and cry about their favourite superstars. Nothing changed when I came to the main roster, I arrived on Smackdown and saw all the kids who love John Cena or Randy Orton, then you knock them down and see the look on their faces, that anger and disappointment, the anger on their faces, the frustration towards me, and that just makes me want to do it again and again and again, and have a blast doing it.\n\nWatch WWE SummerSlam 2017 live on the WWE Network or on Sky Sports Box Office at midnight on Sunday, August 20.\n\nYou can follow all the action as it happens in the Mirror Sport SummerSlam 2017 Live Blog.\n\nWWE Live returns to the UK this November, tickets available at www.bookingsdirect.com.\n\nRead More WWE Mirror Exclusive interviews", "dateTime": "2017-08-18T16:48:00Z", "extractedDates": [{"textEnd": 6300, "textStart": Plus, who do we think will win? Check out all our predictions. By Matt Fowler\n\nOn Sunday, August 20th, WWE SummerSlam roars into the Barclays Center in Brooklyn for a stacked card of action featuring all major titles on the line, a handful of grudge matches (possibly featuring a demon or two), and -- assumedly -- a need to try and outshine NXT: TakeOver Brooklyn III from the night before.\n\nLet's dig into the card and shine a spotlight on the bouts that we're most excited for. From Sasha vs. Alexa to...a late entry in the field of \"Hey, this is actually interesting now,\" John Cena vs. Baron Corbin, here are the 5 matches we can't wait to see.\n\nRaw Women's Champion Alexa Bliss vs. Sasha Banks\n\nCan Sasha break her \"Brooklyn Curse?\" And can it really even be called a curse if Sasha's been in the women's title picture main event three years running (with her first Barclays match being a modern classic back at TakeOver Brooklyn I)? Either way, we're happy to watch both these women fight it out for the RAW Women's Championship (with rumors of their real-life heat fanning the flames of battle), and honestly we'll be happy with either gal winning. Though a Sasha victory will get the biggest pop for sure.\n\nUniversal Champion Brock Lesnar vs. Roman Reigns vs. Samoa Joe vs. Braun Strowman\n\nThe meatiest meatfest in the Meatpacking District, the giant Fatal Fourway for Brock's Universal Championship is going to be a showcase of hellacious slobberknockery. Any one of these guys can win. Brock, with all the misdirect going on about him leaving for UFC, could still just pick up the big win here. And yes, he can still be Universal Champ while doing the MMA thing. That's easy enough. Plus, they've taken the title from him in a multi-man match before so to do it again would be cliche at this point.\n\nStill, never count out Roman Reigns (ugh) and him being the default \"Guy/Dog.\" The biggest shocks (and biggest pops, most definitely) here would be Braun or Joe winning the title and becoming first time WWE world champs. Whatever the outcome, and whatever happens with the Shield reunion that we're all phantom booking in our brains, this is going to be a massively terrific contest.\n\nRaw Tag Team Champions Cesaro & Sheamus vs. Dean Ambrose & Seth Rollins\n\nBoth tag team championship matches on the 'Slam card seem really strong (though we're sad Usos/New Day is on the pre-show), but it's the former-enemies-turned-frenemies whirlwind for the RAW tag titles that's keeping us glued. While it seems likely that Ambrose and Rollins will have too many issues to fully gel as a team, the same can almost be said of Shesaro too, given the way those two started out. This contest is anyone's call, but one thing we do know is that it'll be excellent. And if Seth and Dean win, we'll all be predicting a Shield swerve for the main event.\n\nUnited States Champion AJ Styles vs. Kevin Owens\n\nAdding Shane McMahon (Joe Pesci Lethal Weapon 3 poster style) to the Styles/Owens feud was the best thing to happen to the U.S. title picture right now. Not that these two superb stars couldn't deliver on their own, but after a few months you need to add a bit more spice to the stew (spice that isn't \"dangling Enzo in a shark cage\"). It's a great way to get Shane into some ring acton without giving him an actual match (that he'll probably lose). The build here has been a lot of fun too, with both AJ and Kevin having accidentally clocked Shane-O on the way to Sunday's card.\n\nJohn Cena vs. Baron Corbin\n\nOriginally, in this fifth spot, was the Jinder Mahal/Shinsuke Nakamura match, but ever since Corbin's big flub on this past week's SmackDown Live, this match has become a \"make or break\" affair for him. Having that MITB contract almost guaranteed Baron a world championship and now he's been booked to seem like one of the biggest chowderheads in WWE history. A loss to Cena now, even though it's Cena, will be devastating. Is this where Corbin gets to shine? He'll either have to pull off a stunning win or get so close to winning that he gets some type of respectful m'lady fedora tip from Cena for him to be able to keep his head above water.\n\nSummerSlam Match Predictons\n\nIt's one thing to just predict and list which matches are likely to steal the show, but what about the outcomes? Who do we think will win? His supporters steadfastly defend him; his detractors boo him mercilessly.\n\nAnd if his latest crowning moment happens inside the Barclays Center, WWE won't be happy with the reaction.\n\nFor one, Brooklyn, New York, is a fanbase heavy with \"smarks,\" the same diehard portion of the audience that has pushed back against Reigns' rise. Like Chicago, Philadelphia and Toronto, the Brooklyn crowd is often outspoken, favors internet darlings and has seemingly made a sport of booing Reigns.\n\nWhen Raw traveled to the Barclays Center last August, the fans treated The Big Dog like the heel despite him going up against the conniving, villainous Chris Jericho.\n\nReigns bowled over Jericho with a shoulder block and boos rained down. Jericho locked his foe in the Walls of Jericho and the crowd roared in approval.\n\nAgainst Brock Lesnar, Braun Strowman and Samoa Joe at SummerSlam, Reigns can expect the same treatment.\n\nA good number of fans will be rooting for Joe and Strowman to emerge with the universal title in hand. Joe's lengthy journey to this point, through Ring of Honor, TNA and Japan, makes him easy to pull for. He has immense street cred, so to speak, with diehard fans.\n\nThe hosts of the Tights and Fights podcast are clearly behind Joe:\n\nAnd they aren't alone. Corey Jacobs of WrestlingNews.co wrote an article entitled \"It's Time for WWE to Put the Universal Championship on Samoa Joe.\" Daily DDT's Alexander Podgorski posted five reasons Joe should win on Sunday.\n\nThere's a similar push for Strowman to take the crown.\n\nHis destructive ways on Raw have endeared him to fans in a big way. {"id": "9560897", "categories": [{"id": 41, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 115, "label": "dmoz/Society/People", "uri": "dmoz/Society/People", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 116, "label": "dmoz/Society/People/Generations and Age Groups", "uri": "dmoz/Society/People/Generations_and_Age_Groups", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 552, "label": "dmoz/Shopping/Jewelry/Watches", "uri": "dmoz/Shopping/Jewelry/Watches", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 553, "label": "dmoz/Business/Consumer Goods and Services/Jewelry", "uri": "dmoz/Business/Consumer_Goods_and_Services/Jewelry", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 808, "label": "dmoz/Shopping/Antiques and Collectibles/Clocks and Watches", "uri": "dmoz/Shopping/Antiques_and_Collectibles/Clocks_and_Watches", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 1055, "label": "dmoz/Sports/Wrestling", "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Wrestling", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 1056, "label": "dmoz/Sports/Wrestling/Amateur", "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Wrestling/Amateur", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 1184, "label": "dmoz/Sports/Wrestling/Professional", "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Wrestling/Professional", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 1404, "label": "dmoz/Recreation/Humor/Parodies", "uri": "dmoz/Recreation/Humor/Parodies", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-16", "uri": "710533462", "source": {"id": "2887", "title": "Golf Digest", "uri": "golfdigest.com"}, "url": "https://www.golfdigest.com/story/a-spandex-skeptics-guide-to-wwe-summerslam-2017", "body": "Before Mayweather vs. McGregor, before Canelo vs. Golovkin, and (hopefully) before this entire planet sheers off its axis and goes spinning into the formless vacuum of space like an errant frisbee, we, combat sport-loving citizens of a post-Coliseum world, must first survive [the opening notes of Scorpions' \"No One Like You\" wail over the loudspeaker] WWE SUMMERSLAM 2017!\n\nNow I know what you're thinking: Wrestling? Still? But as millenials' biological need to be ensconced in nostalgia at every waking moment has intensified, so has the demand for the WWE. Revenue is up 10% year over year, WWE Network subscriptions have skyrocketed to well over 1.6 million, and total video across the brand's social media platforms recently eclipsed 4 billion (with a B). In other words, if you're NOT watching, you're the exception, not the rule.\n\nBut don't worry. The WWE's second biggest PPV event of the year may be mere days away, but we're here to help, getting you up to speed on everything you missed while you were busy being an adult for the past decade. So grab that fold-up chair and rub me down in baby oil, because it's time to send this one off the top rope.\n\nI think I remember SummerSlam as a trace element in the Mountain Dew/Halo/Cheeto dust swirl of my youth. Refresh my bong-fried memory again? SummerSlam is World Wrestling Entertainment's summer tentpole event which, if you can't guess by the name, features plenty of sweaty bedazzled man slamming in an arena full of other sweaty (significantly less bedazzled) men. To use a clunky every-sport analogy, if WrestleMania is WWE's Super Bowl -- and it is -- then SummerSlam is its Pro Bowl: Sunnier, funnier, and teeming with sentient muscle balls wearing Hawaiian shirts like they hoped they were going to be the only one to think of that.\n\nBoy, what a glowing endorsement. Maybe I'll just watch Thrones instead... Well, actually, if you like Game of Thrones, there's plenty of demo crossover here. 2016 SummerSlam breakthrough, Finn B\u00e1lor -- who's been out for almost a year following a shoulder injury sustained in last year's inaugural Universal Belt bout -- is set to revive his dormant \"Demon King\" shtick for a grudge match with Bray Wyatt. Meanwhile, Brock Lesnar is pretty much The Mountain. Sure, there are no dragons, but it can't be Christmas every day either.\n\nIf you watch 60 Minutes on Sunday nights and fancy yourself a Serious Person\u2122, however, I strongly suggest you have a few beers before attempting to turn into the spin. I'm a miserable, dignified f -- k too, but if you give it a chance, you'll be amazed what watching a bunch of pleather panty-clad women (or men, whatever works for you) beat the shit out of each other on live TV can do for your mental health.\n\nDid someone say pleather panties? OK, I'm in. So what are the major storylines I should, uhh, buff up on? As always, it's all about Brock Lesnar. The only dude to ever successfully crossover from sports entertainment to actual sports (and back again) has been setting up a return to UFC for several months, and SummerSlam looks like it could finally be the catalyst. Lesnar will be competing in a Fatal 4-Way --\n\nWait, wait, wait: Fatal 4-Way? A four-hulk free-for-all. No teams, no rules, just right.\n\nOK, go on... against fellow prehistoric rock monsters Roman Reigns, Samoa Joe, and Braun Strowman in a battle to retain the Universal Championship (don't ask, we doubt even Vince McMahon could explain it). Due to the \"random\" (and by random we mean obsessively scripted) nature of the Fatal 4-Way, however, Lesnar's sideshow manager, Paul Heyman, has already gone on record saying that if Lesnar loses the belt, he will walk away from the WWE.\n\nExpect Lesnar to lose the belt.\n\nThat's not the only match though right? Not. Even. Close. In addition to a full slate of Saturday action from the WWE's increasingly popular feeder league, NXT, the main SummerSlam fight card also includes New Japan Wrestling sensation Shinsuke Nakamura -- think Thriller-era Michael Jackson crossed with the Drunken Master -- battling Jinder Mahal for the WWE Championship, Alexa Bliss and Sasha Banks facing off for the incrementally de-sexualized Raw Women's Championship, and midtown-Irish-pub-level parody Sheamus teaming up with Cesaro to fend off white trash heartthrob, Dean Ambrose, and reformed dick-pic-er, Seth Rollins, for the Raw Tag Team Championship.\n\nSounds like my family reunion... ZING! And as if that wasn't enough speedo-and-bondage-boot action for you and your suddenly interested girlfriend, John Cena -- who you've probably actually heard of -- is set to wrestle Baron Corbin, while fan favorites AJ Styles and Kevin Owens will fake-punch it out for the United States Championship, with the comish's son, Shane McMahon, serving as the guest referee. Shane is best known for his death-defying leaps in and around the ring (and for surviving a recent helicopter crash), though, so expect him to male-stripper tear his too-small zebra stripes off and flatten someone like an asphalt roller at some point. Hell, maybe he'll even win the belt. Who knows, sometimes I swear they make this shit up as they go.\n\nThat's a lot to process, even if you are one of the 12 college-educated viewers. Any tips on who to root for? Sure. Maybe these pocket bios will help.\n\nAny other insider advice? Yeah, make sure to load up on snacks -- anything with \"nacho\" flavoring will do -- and cardboard vats of fried chicken, if readily available in your area of West Virginia. SummerSlam is like seven grueling hours of all America, all the time, and you'll need to periodically refuel if you want to have anything left for that Monster Truck rally tomorrow.\n\nAlso, try not to mention it in front of your office IT guy, unless you want to spend half the morning searching your desk for something stab into your earholes while he grandstands about The Miz's inauthentic ego-worship, only to realize you loaned your scissors to Steve last week and this is your fate now, you stupid, stupid idiot.\n\nSo say I hypothetically wanted to watch this thing, you know, as a sociological experiment or whatever, how would I do it? Well, if it's an immersive societal examination you're after, head on down to Barclays Center on Sunday night, where half of Pennsylvania, some of New Jersey, and most of Long Island will be found in a state of mutually suspended reality.\n\nIf you'd prefer a nostalgia experience far from the prying eyes of anyone you'll ever have to see again in your entire life, however, then pay-per-view or a WWE Network subscription (boy, you really got into this, huh?) should do the trick. Either way, go in with an open mind and -- if you're watching with friends who are fans -- zipped lips. {"id": "9795454", "categories": [{"id": 32, "label": "dmoz/Sports/Football/American", "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Football/American", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 49, "label": "dmoz/Games", "uri": "dmoz/Games", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 111, "label": "dmoz/Arts/Television", "uri": "dmoz/Arts/Television", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 212, "label": "dmoz/Arts/Television/Programs", "uri": "dmoz/Arts/Television/Programs", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 713, "label": "dmoz/Games/Roleplaying/Genres", "uri": "dmoz/Games/Roleplaying/Genres", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 1184, "label": "dmoz/Sports/Wrestling/Professional", "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Wrestling/Professional", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-17", "uri": "711165361", "source": {"id": "16", "title": "The Sun", "uri": "thesun.co.uk"}, "url": "https://www.thesun.co.uk/sport/4267759/summerslam-finn-balor-brock-lesnar-kurt-angle-triple-h-daniel-bryan/", "body": "Summer's biggest event has proved to be a huge springboard for superstars in the past\n\nWITH SummerSlam just around the corner, we have taken a look at some of the most iconic match-ups in recent history.\n\nSummerSlam has been the catalyst to superstardom for many wrestlers with Finn Balor, Brock Lesnar, Kurt Angle, Triple H and Daniel Bryan all thriving under the spotlight.\n\nTake a read of the below to see just how big an impact SummerSlam has had on each superstar in getting to where they are now.\n\nAny modern WWE fan will know the story of Finn Balor's dream and nightmare SummerSlam.\n\nTaking the NXT world by storm, he became the longest reigning NXT Champion at 292 days.\n\nFinn was then drafted to Raw as the fifth overall pick in the 2016 WWE draft, and made his debut on the 25 July - The Demon King's 35th birthday.\n\nIt was a birthday to remember, as he defeated Rusev, Cesaro and Kevin Owens in a Fatal- 4-way, and went on to beat Roman Reigns in a match that meant he would compete for the new WWE Universal Championship at SummerSlam 2016.\n\nBalor went toe-to-toe with Seth Rollins in a savage battle. At one point in the match, Seth performed a running powerbomb and slammed Finn into the safety barrier outside the ring, and disaster struck.\n\nFinn suffered a 180 degree labrum tear, a torn bicep and pectoral tendon, cartilage damage and a fracture to the glenoid neck socket.\n\nThis wasn't enough to thwart The Demon King, however, as he went to defeat Seth Rollins with his patented Coup De Grace and became the first ever WWE Universal Champion.\n\nHe also became the first ever Superstar to relinquish the Title, as his injuries were too severe to continue in the ring for several months.\n\nBalor is currently on the road back to the top, most recently ending his rivalry with Elias and is now in the midst of mind games with The Eater of Worlds, Bray Wyatt, who he faces this Sunday at SummerSlam.\n\nBrock Lesnar was the specimen that blasted on the scene in 2002, attacking Al Snow, Maven and Spike Dudley, with the latter being on the receiving end of a devastating triple powerbomb. And who was by his side? None other than The Advocate, Paul Heyman, who was seen barking orders.\n\nAt the time, Brock was nicknamed \"The Next Big Thing\", and boy were they right. His first feud was with The Hardy Boyz, defeating them at multiple PPVs including Backlash and Judgement Day.\n\nAfter winning the King of the Ring final against RVD, Brock earned his WWE Undisputed Championship shot against The Rock at SummerSlam 2002. Brock executed his own Rock Bottom and F5, and with the help of an interference from Paul Heyman, he landed the big time and won his first championship.\n\nBrock began to make an even bigger name for himself as he went to war with The Undertaker at No Mercy, defeating him in a Hell in a Cell match.\n\nWe all know how The Deadman and The Beast's rivalry progressed in the future.\n\nLesnar went on to feud with Big Show, the feud that led Paul Heyman to betray him. Lesnar would suffer his first pin fall loss to Show at Survivor Series, which catapulted his reputation with the fans, and went on to do great things with the company.\n\nKurt Angle's first appearance at WWE came in 1999, quickly establishing his American Hero character based on his gold medal win at the 1998 Summer Olympics.\n\nAfter his initial stint as a \"good guy\", fans quickly began to boo his entrances, which Kurt quickly capitalised on and turned into a villain, patronising his fellow Superstars and the audience themselves.\n\nJust a year later, Angle won the European Championship and the Intercontinental Championship, and then losing both titles without ever conceding a fall in a two-pin Triple Threat match at WrestleMania 2000.\n\nWith these two Titles a distant memory, he then became a top-tier Superstar, feuding with The Rock and Triple H which led to a Triple Threat Match at SummerSlam. Angle was stretchered out during the match after a Pedigree through the announcement table.\n\nAs The People's Champion and The King of Kings battled on, Kurt would be brought back in alongside Vince McMahon to take on Triple H, but after a tussle between The Game and Kurt over a sledgehammer, Vince was on the receiving end of a bash.\n\nWith Kurt and Triple H distracted, the Rock threw the American Hero over the ropes, and then pinned The Game after dishing out The People's Elbow.\n\nSummerSlam would be the catalyst to spark his career. He would go on to have a heated rivalry with Triple H, with Kurt frequently interfering in The Game's matches and ruining his title opportunities.\n\nThey'd go on to do battle a week before Unforgiven, as Angle attacked Triple H with a sledgehammer, leading to the American Hero kissing Stephanie McMahon as her husband lay unconscious in the ring.\n\nTriple H earned vengeance at Unforgiven, but Kurt would go on to have one of the greatest rivalries in recent memories against Stone Cold Steve Austin.\n\nSummerSlam 1998 was nicknamed \"Highway to Hell\", with a fierce main card on the table. Stone Cold was due to defend his title against The Undertaker, Ken Shamrock had a huge bout with Owen Hart, and X-Pac battled Jeff Jarret, but it was the two young guns that stole the show - The Rock and Triple H.\n\nThe two up and coming Superstars faced off in a Ladder Match for the Intercontinental Title, with carnage ensuing. After weaponising the ladder to both their advantages, Chyna delivered a low blow to The Rock which allowed HHH to win the Intercontinental Title.\n\nUnfortunately, Triple H would be sidelined with a knee injury and gave up the title, but while he was away The Rock went on to win the WWF Championship at Survivor Series.\n\nThe two would reignite their rivalry in an I Quit match, The Rock accompanied by Kane and The Game by Chyna. Much to Triple H's dismay, he was forced to say I Quit to stop Kane chokeslamming Chyna.\n\nHowever, Chyna later attacked Triple H, showing that she planned to betray him all along.\n\nThe Game would then go on to have one of his most memorable heel turns, and become a part of The Corporation.\n\nDaniel Bryan is the Rocky of the WWE Universe - the true underdog story that everyone wanted to succeed. His unconventional looks, his smaller frame, his wild facial hair, it was everything that the WWE hadn't seen in a Title contender before. But nobody resonated with the fans better than the do-or-die Daniel Bryan.\n\nBefore SummerSlam 2013, the Team Hell No tag-team was formed of Bryan and Kane, where they would often bicker between themselves during matches. They would go on to have a successful run as WWE Tag Team Champions, feuding with the likes of Team Rhodes Scholars, 3MB and, later down the line, The Shield, who they lost the titles to.\n\nBryan became obsessed to prove he wasn't the weak link of Team Hell No and launched the \"Yes!' movement, becoming more aggressive in the process.\n\nThis was the year he began to become the Superstar that put his name in lights. After Team Hell No separated, Bryan went on to better Randy Orton in a rivalry, and continued his hot streak by picking up wins over Sheamus and Christian.\n\nThe crowd was pining for Bryan to win the Money in the Bank that year, but was foiled by Curtis Axel, a non-participant, with Randy Orton picking up the win.\n\nHowever, the crowd would have their dreams come true as John Cena picked Bryan to be his opponent at SummerSlam 2013. This is where The Corporation began to dampen any hopes Bryan would have at victory by psychologically and physically damaging him. Bryan was labelled the 'B+ Player', he was put through gauntlet matches, and was made to face his old tag-team partner Kane.\n\nNone of that mattered, as Cena and Bryan went hammer and tong, as the Yes Man beat the odds to become the WWE Champion. Special referee Triple H, however, had other plans, and planted a Pedigree to Bryan. Orton would cash in his Money in the Bank and cut the title reign short.\n\nSummerSlam would further propel his connection with the crowd, and went on to create the biggest atmospheres in stadiums across the world from his matches - he'd feud with The Corporation, Randy Orton, and the up and coming Bray Wyatt.\n\nBryan would go on to main event WrestleMania XXX, defeating Batista and Randy {"id": "9975099", "categories": [{"id": 285, "label": "dmoz/Society/History", "uri": "dmoz/Society/History", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 286, "label": "dmoz/Society/History/By Time Period", "uri": "dmoz/Society/History/By_Time_Period", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 1055, "label": "dmoz/Sports/Wrestling", "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Wrestling", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 1184, "label": "dmoz/Sports/Wrestling/Professional", "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Wrestling/Professional", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-18", "uri": "711656260", "source": {"id": "2639", "title": "The Inquisitr News", "uri": "inquisitr.com"}, "url": "http://www.inquisitr.com/4439198/wwe-star-roman-reigns-talks-about-john-cena-match-but-when-might-it-happen/", "body": "Could a Roman Reigns vs. John Cena WWE match be happening soon? It just might happen based on recent comments from \"The Big Dog\" when asked about battling the 16-time WWE champion. Current WWE free agent John Cena has been a member of the professional wrestling organization for quite some time now but has yet to engage in a one-on-one match with the former member of The Shield. Both starts are on different brands within WWE currently, although these two stars seem destined to collide. Does Roman Reigns want it to happen, though?\n\nThe current WWE Raw roster member is battling in a Fatal 4-Way this coming Sunday at WWE's SummerSlam 2017 PPV. He'll take on Samoa Joe, Braun Strowman, and Brock Lesnar for the WWE Universal Championship. Cena will be involved in a match booked on SmackDown Live as he takes on former \"Mr. Money in the Bank\" Baron Corbin. Still, Reigns was recently interviewed by Sports Illustrated and spoke on several topics including his promo in the ring on Raw one night after defeating The Undertaker at WrestleMania 33. Reigns said he felt he \"had everyone on a string\" in that moment and that he even realized he was eating into time for another match on the Raw card.\n\nSo now that he's cleared one of WWE's top superstars of all-time, what about John Cena? Reigns commented on whether or not he wants to have a match with him in the future.\n\n\"I think so. If you're here for the right reasons -- and this doesn't just go for wrestling, this is anything, this is what drives our world -- you wanna be in there with the best. To say John Cena is not one of the best of all time is asinine. He is. He's a 16-time heavyweight champion. There's only two men in the whole world that can say that. So to be able to share the ring with him, to do a big fight with John Cena, I'm all for that.\"\n\nReigns goes on to mention that he didn't come to WWE just to \"blend in\" but to \"stick out.\"\n\n\"I'm stepping up. I think I've proved that over the years. I think, what a great way to honor both of our careers and what we're trying to do and the way we try to drive this train. What better way to do it than in the ring, one on one.\"\n\nWhile there's no rumored match planned between Roman Reigns and John Cena, it's been talked about for quite a while now. WWE has teased it. Fans have discussed it. The two competitors even traded tweet jabs at one another last month. Now they'll be part of the same WWE pay-per-view this weekend, and free agent John Cena is reportedly heading to the WWE Raw program to compete in the weeks after the PPV event. That could set up a Reigns vs. Cena WWE match at some point very soon.\n\nBoth superstars could very well stake a claim towards the WWE Universal Championship unless Reigns has won it this Sunday. It's a prize that John Cena has yet to win and it could be the one he wins to break Ric Flair's record of major championship reigns. As to when this match might happen involving Cena vs. Reigns, that's anyone's guess. WWE loves to tease and build up to epic matches for major PPV events. The biggest is next year's WrestleMania 34 in New Orleans. There's also the Royal Rumble 2018 in January. Ironically, both Reigns and Cena are currently tied as favorites for the Paddy Power betting odds to win that Rumble match. If one wins, could the other be the champion they face at Mania?\n\nThe two will probably be face-to-face soon. It would not be all that surprising to have John Cena and Roman Reigns cross paths in some capacity once Cena starts working on WWE's Raw show more. Whether that is during a Cena or Reigns' promo in the ring, or an actual booked match of some sort, it should be interesting to see what transpires. Most likely, WWE teases a match but it doesn't happen until a bigger event than Raw. However, in the mind of Roman Reigns and many fans, this match with John Cena will happen one day in the future.
